on monday, when singapore prime minister lee hsien loong touched down on japan, chinese air force projected a show of force near japan, to which japanese airforce jets scrambled. below is a press conference of china's foreign ministry while prime minister lee is in japan. prime minister lee needs all the diplomacy, skill, finesse, subtlety and tact to navigate his relations with china and japan while he is visiting japan and china is criticising singapore.
Q: Chinese media reported that, during the just concluded 17th Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM), Singapore along with a few other countries, irrespective of clear opposition from a majority of members, insisted on highlighting the South China Sea-related contents in the outcome document. Singapore recently said that these reports are groundless and fail to tell the facts. What is your comment?
A: We have noted relevant reports.
NAM is not a proper place to discuss the South China Sea issue. Its outcome document shall reflect the consensus of all the members based on the long-held principle of consensus upon consultation. The facts are clear. Individual countries insisted on highlighting the South China Sea-related contents in the outcome document, but failed in doing so, because they did not secure the approval of the majority of NAM members and these contents did not represent the consensus of parties related to the South China Sea issue, China being one party.
Thanks to the concerted efforts of China and ASEAN states, the current situation in the South China Sea is moving towards a positive direction. China hopes that relevant countries can respect China's stance and relevant consensus reached between China and ASEAN, uphold an objective and unbiased position, and make constructive contributions to the sound and steady development of China-ASEAN relations and the proper settlement of the South China Sea issue.
Q: Considering a series of reports on what happened during the 17th NAM Summit, will the friendly relationship between China and Singapore be affected?
A: China and Singapore established the All-Round Cooperative Partnership Progressing with the Times last year. I want to stress that on issues concerning the core interests and major concerns of the two sides, China and Singapore should understand and respect each other.

The passing away of a titan!  He will be forever remembered as a fine statesman and a diplomat extraordinaire.  Married to a Bengali Hindu woman, this highly erudite Singaporean Tamil did everything in his capacity to turn an economically backward Singapore into an envy of the whole world.  Besides, he was part of that generation of Singaporean Tamils, who produced some of the country's brightest and most talented civil servants and leaders.  In him, LKY found a comrade and a confidant, and Singapore a visionary leader and guardian.  The world - and certainly Singapore - is much worse off with his demise.

My family, friends and I are deeply saddened by the news of the demise of the 6th President of Singapore, Mr. S. R. Nathan. 

He was an extraordinary man whose nature was down-to-earth, humble, kind hearted and of all a great man who marked religious, moral and social cohesion for the Nation, Community and Society. 

With great intellectual honesty, he did not hesitate to review the poverty for the needy and at the same time, he piloted streams of charity events to raise funds. 

Throughout he observed human beings in all dimensions in order to establish a new civilization that would be more realistic and enduring: the civilization of love. 

The loss of this great man who led an honourable life has made a deep impression on the minds and hearts of all Singaporeans. 

His vision of life was truly remarkable. His teachings and guidance also strengthened us and made us more determined to act with greater equity. These are the sentiments with which we should follow. 

We are all mourning this great man, with sincere grief, for we have lost the true friend of our human journey, and the sentiment we all feel in these days is profound loneliness. 

We would like to express our sincere Heartfelt Condolences on the loss of the great man and our hearts go out to the family of Mdm. Urmila, loved ones and extended families! 

May his divine soul be blessed and rest in peace! 

Death only comes to those who leave no memories; for whose existence was cherished, they will always be alive in the chambers of the heart. 

With Deepest Sympathy,

Subash Saminathan
Ester Kristina
Rowshaun Subash
Yatminah &
Verdina Devi Andani Family & Friends

Grateful PM Lee resumed his NDR at 10.40pm on a high note and ended his speech at 10.58pm with these key words:

Divine Discontent

Material things.

Simply wonderful.

He will need lots of rest under close observation by his medic team.

======

PM Lee said at the NDR:

Recently, somebody asked me at a dialogue "If God appeared before you and asked you for three things that you would want for Singapore, what would these be?"

I was taken aback. I thought for a while and replied: If we wish for material things, we will regret it, because after we have got it, we will not be satisfied and we will want more. 

But what I would like is that we be blessed with a divine discontent - always dissatisfied with where we are; always driven to do better. 

And yet, that we have the wisdom to count our blessings, so that we know how precious Singapore is, and we know how to enjoy and protect it.

If just these two wishes are fulfilled, that will be enough. Then we can keep on building something special in Singapore for many more years, and "Achieve Happiness, Prosperity, and Progress, for our nation".

Thank you and Good Night

Saturday, July 30, 2016 

We welcome Mahathir's new party 

Salleh Said Keruak 

Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad has finally admitted that the only way to change the government is in a general election. Of course, Mahathir will not admit that he is trying to change the government. He claims he is just trying to remove Prime Minister Najib Tun Razak to save Umno, Barisan Nasional and Malaysia. It is strange that someone would want to save the party that he claims he still loves by trying to destroy it. It is like saying that you want to save humanity by destroying the world. Anyway, there is no longer any doubt that Mahathir wants to form a new party plus launch a new opposition coalition so that he can defeat Umno and Barisan Nasional in the general election. 

And I personally welcome that move because at least it now makes Mahathir's stand very clear and prove that he is not trying to save Umno but to defeat Umno. 

Sometimes competition is good when it make you aware that unless you buck up and work harder you face the risk of defeat. Countries like Japan and Germany excelled because they had to struggle to survive whereas Empires such as Britain faded away due to rot and complacency. So maybe Mahathir is doing Umno and Barisan Nasional a favour by offering us some competition because competition is always good to see success.

The other problem at home
In the UK, a problem which I don't think singapore has, is that back home there are no legal repercussions if you lie during your campaign. Within hours of the leave win, the lure of $350 million being pumped into the NHS was revealed to not be true or possible. It was revealed by one of the leading leave politicians, and he must have known it before voting commenced. I don't believe that such a falsehood would have been tolerated politically in singapore. In the UK such a lure would have gained significant votes from poorer less educated people.
What could you do if a politician lied? You will be stuck with them for another five years.

To be fair though, where does it say on that bus ¬£350 million will go to the NHS each week?  The answer is it doesn't.  It says quite clearly on that bus "let's fund our NHS instead".  It does not say how much of this money is going to the NHS.  It only implies that some will.

The media is spinning this story saying that certain people "promised" things they actually never did.  People have put two and two together and ended up with minus six.

Ironic really that they then have the audacity to say that it was the educated who voted to remain.

"The majority of the educated class voting to stay; the less educated to leave. Those doing well in their jobs and incomes voting to stay; those who felt they've been losing out voted to leave."

Jerome Chan is obviously a 'leaver'.

http://www.theguardian.com/politics/reality-check/2016/may/23/does-the-eu-really-cost-the-uk-350m-a-week

There's a picture of your bus being just rather less than clear about 'just sending a bit to the NHS' and clearing up the lie about the EU costing 350 million a week.
And that's how it works on the less educated.

Firstly, you clearly didn't read what I typed because I quoted the message on the bus.  I was going to post a picture of the bus myself, but figured I had relayed the information perfectly by text.  What is worrying is that you posted the picture of the bus and apparently don't understand what the words mean.  

Really?  You actually thought the entire amount we send to the EU (some of which is given back to fund schools, etc...) would be spent soley on the NHS?

Not a full shilling are you.

Dan Hallows dislike. 

I am with Charlotte. If you meant to spend just SOME of the 350m on the NHS, put the word "SOME" on the bus please.

It's obvious that it's not the full amount.  I guess you're not "educated" enough to understand.

There are always 2 sides to the same coin. Many will be hurt economically by the decision but many others will benefit. While there is a possibility that those in the industrial cities voting for Brexit may be hurt by its economic consequences, there is also the possibility that they may be better off. There is no telling that continued increase in immigration from EU will not hurt them even more compared to the economic consequences of Brexit. In fact, I think financial centres like Singapore will likely benefit in the medium term, as will international students in UK from outside the EU. The logic could be a simple one.  It is NOT about $$$.  If open borders in EU mean young voters voted for passport sake; accessibility (no pre-requisites) to any part of EU seeking employments; forsaking family nucleus and ties; leaving silver generations at home...then the outcome is a logical one.
The older, matured and wiser generations have voted not for their selfish sake but for molding future generations and protecting institutions (eg multi generation family) vital for UK sovereignty, family roots and identity. Open borders have unintended consequences; putting stresses and constraints on many family businesses, family trees and identity.  Families have become more nomadic and always on the roads or air.  People no longer can grow deep roots.  Brexit is a reality now.  Clearly British voters have spoken a single language; they are seeking their UK Dream from deep inside their hearts; a Kingdom they once upon a time called Home with Garden of Eden inside.  The grass may not be greener on the outside.  The World should learn from  Brexit.  Modern parents have shared;  when I was a kid my parents are strict, but I always found them.  Today, my grown-up kids are never be found.  They are always busy and out of town; in the clouds.

The failure to meet expectations is always the number one reason for a breakup or divorce in any form of relationship.

If we study the matter hard enough, many mature democratic governments has failed to recognize the "Seeded Expectations" of  citizens.

Immigration seems to be the biggest topic in this new brew of politics. But also one key ingredient that helps anti-immigration sentiments thrive , is the government's failure to align expectations. It's not just the usual expectations that are promised year in year out or at every political campaign. But the seeds of expectations that were planted over the years since the birth of a child that follows through to his/her growing childhood right up to early adulthood. During the period of growing up, a child will get to learn about their rights and they may also develop aspirations base on the mold of society definition of success. In involve the society as a whole, from the parents and right up to the government, all would have some sort of an expectation from the child. Seeded expectation are the sort of expectations that grew up with you and remain within you.

Seeded expectations are more apparent in developed cities with competitive economy due to the availability of a "formula of success". People were told to follow a certain way of life to get the success they were yearning for. It could be hard work, or in the earlier 90's of Singapore context, the necessity of getting a degree. As a child all you need to do is to follow the formula and you will most likely get your success. Common sense will tell you that the more people does the same thing the more often then not the formula won't work as well as it intended to be. When something becomes common, the definition of success has change. The individual will then wonder what success is and how did I turned out to be someone common? Is there a sudden change in expectation? What did I do wrong all these years that I do not stand out?  This sort of situation will trigger a sense of frustration among these young adults, just like the seeds that were planted in them, the issue are deep and personal. (A voting trend that may define the current 30s and above because of the deep seeded expectations that has failed them for years) 

Immigration fundamentally rattles the seeded expectations. Many question will be left unanswered. A mid-career worker may question the hard work he has put in all these years while following the formula to achieve his/her aspiration of success but he/she will also notice the foreigner who bypass the "system" and receive something similar or a position higher then him/her at work. These mid-career workers will question the system.

A British example could be, I'm born a British and it's my every right to receive the social and welfare benefits payout for the hard work I had given to this country over the years. I have contributed my taxes and is due time for me to enjoy the benefits ..... but then why on earth are these immigrants or EU citizen enjoying the same benefits as me? How could they just bypass the formula or system? These people don't deserve a cent from our British system. 

It maybe the general sentiment of the older generation in Britain, educated or not.The majority felt they were loosing out and they had to act on a vote that benefits them. They may not understand the whole context of the consequence of leaving the EU.

Well in Singapore at least, we know that globalization and a declining birth rate in many developed cities has forced the hands of governments to accept immigrants.
Competition between countries, cities and maybe even businesses has played a role in recruiting talents from around the world. Governments has traded immigration for the better of a robust economy. But could they have also traded their votes because they may have neglected the "seeded expectations". 

When someone whom has dedicated his/her life all these years to attain something and when they reach that point of life to grab it but it isn't there, i think people will be frustrated and they will be angry. 

Tharman Shanmugaratnam I m not sure if what I called seeded expectation is something that has been studied or talked about before but I hope that the government is aware of it's existence. 

A sense of failure lurks around the individual when deep rooted expectations are not met. Emotions will precede over logic. The failure to meet expectations is always the number one reason for a breakup or divorce in any form of relationship. When people don't get what they expected, it is where it all ends.

For the rich and businessmen who benefit from the present policies they voted to stay. But for those who do not benefit they would want to give a try on the other path as they felt there is still a slim chance for them to see light at the end of road.

With immigration, once done it cannot easily be undone. It is not like a tap. You turn off the tap and everything is fine. There is still flood water everywhere. People with the responsibility to devise immigration and population policies must plan with a very long horizon. 

It's the same with productivity and skills. These cannot be gained overnight. You cannot ask "Where are the engineers?" only when you need them. I have a suggestion to make. Why don't the Government give out scholarships for engineering and any other speciality that we need, not for use by the Government but for use by the private sector? Bond these scholars to work in these private organizations in their specialities of study and have the companies co-share the cost of the scholarships. The Government must be generous. Otherwise there will be no takers.

Corporations should not be allowed to expect more public welfare with yet another govt sponsored scholarship/bonds. Singapore has been successful with steering graduates of required qualifications. Many companies had worked with universities to award top performers a final year or a guaranteed position. 
We have no lack of engineers but who would not want to climb and achieve higher if they can? 
Retaining workers doesn't work with bonds. Retaining an employee unwilling to stay will not have productive outcome.

Retaining graduates or employees are multi-pronged which I find severely lacking especially in local managed organisations. Gratification at work via opportunities to gain experience, perform, to be appreciated openly can sometimes be powerful retention factors. Unfortunately local management are often (not all are) micro-managing, unappreciative and not very fair on remuneration (short-sighted) and with high tendency of rewarding  talkers than real achievers. 

Corporations are turning to foreign PMETS mainly for cost and obedience. Productivity often suffers. Other than complying with mandatory work safety and relevant laws, an employee should not be expected to be meek and obedient if you want diversity, creativity and high productivity. Learn to manage, not control your employees and be fair with sharing the rewards. That way, we wouldn't need so many migrant PMET workers.

Although there are many engineering students but many end up doing non-engineering work. I am sure the same applies to other areas of expertise. Singapore does not have a culture of dedication in developing one's expertise. Many look for shortcuts to instant wealth and accordingly lead to a shortage of engineering expertise. 

Those who have the responsibility to recruit engineers face this problem of shortage and have to rely on foreign engineers, who could come with questionable certifications. It is not always a question of cost. When you advertise for a position a dozen times and not a single Singaporean or even a PR applies for the vacancy, cost is not the issue here. 

If we are not willing to think out of the box, we will continue to have to rely on foreign workers together with all the attendant problems that come with it, including, ironically, a higher cost of living. And this is not welfare or further contribution to the private enterprises because they will have to pay the local market prices for these scholars and moreover have to continue to recruit them for the duration of the bond. This carries a business risk. The bulk of the benefits of the scholarship goes to the student, answering to the complaint that  too many scholarships have gone to foreigners. Further, breaking the bond, on either side could incur penalties to be paid back to the Government. The Government simply pays for the scholarships to correct a resource imbalance. 

Without a solution to encourage local workers to fill vacancies of need, we will forever be dependent on an increasingly larger and larger number of immigrants. That is the market reality.

Harmony and peace is a dynamic state which needs various adjustment/equilibration. The more extreme the establishment goes, the more the other end of the polarised society will want to go. The prolonged short-term and myopic, economy first and people as tools instead of people first and economy as tool. The reversal of the goal and the means has exacerbated the polarization. As such this is a very natural re-equilibration that no one should be surprised with. 
Immigration justified and referenced as a necessity as seen in history is a very selective and unrealistic way of argument for the sole purpose of (post Reagan/Thatcher's privatisation and free market policies) keeping labour cost on one end and shifting wealth to avoid taxes on the other. 
Less violent migration in history was into land that had plenty of opportunity for development (Malaysia, Singapore to name a few). Sovereign countries that were 'migrated into' in large numbers were often more violent than present days -eg Israel/Palestine, Rohingya/Myanmar. So the success/necessity of migrants esp in Singapore's history is not applicable to present Singapore. Immigrants can be introduced at a rate as fast as assimilation can take place. Migration that is too rapid will deter assimilation and build tension. This is natural human nature and to expect otherwise will require a society that is open minded and civically and politically, Singapore is drifting everyday further and further away from open mindedness. 
Brexit is a natural and necessary steering for UK. Just as a bubble economy, to reduce the impact, it is better to burst the bubble while it is small rather than to procrastinate for fear of a small ripple. 
The fundamentals are more difficult to change than corporate greed. Corporate greed is to be regulated by governments. To expect self regulation by the market has been proven time and time again as delusional and irresponsible.

Thanks to everyone, for this whole round of comments. Varying views, but it's clear that Brexit matters to all of us, well beyond the UK. And while there is great uncertainty ahead, it will take a while before Brexit's consequences become clear.                                 The demographic summary  - about who voted for the UK to remain or leave -  that's factual and has been reported extensively. It paints a picture of the broad social divides that showed up in the referendum. They will have implications for the future, and the thinking and ground politics of the major political parties in the UK - as is already being debated, post-referendum. 

But just to be clear -  the demographic generalisations obviously don't describe every voter in each category, as some of you have pointed out. A significant minority of the young, those with degrees, and those better-off, and even of the Scots, voted to leave. And a significant minority of older voters, those without degrees, and those less well-off, voted for UK to remain, against the general currents. More important, the statistics don't say who was wiser.   

It will take years before we know what the outcome of Brexit, economically and politically will be - for the UK and its constituent parts, and equally important for Europe. It will have relevance everywhere: The geopolitics that evolves from here (see for eg this opinion piece below). The lessons we each derive in our own settings - for policies that aim to preserve trust and inclusivity in society, even as we stay open to the world; a sense that everyone matters and must share in prosperity.  And critically, for how we strengthen the politics of reason, and the politics of the centre.  Let's keep our minds open.

The benefits of globalization / remaining within the EU brings with it benefits, but not without costs. Excellent breakdown. Finally a piece that talks sense rather than brand "leave" or "remain" as educated or uneducated, xenophobic, ignorant or hate. Couldn't have explained it better. 

1. The invocation of 'hate' has become a way of dismissing opponents by suggesting that their beliefs are beyond the reach of reason.

2. The anti-Brexit crowd cannot acknowledge that those who voted to leave may have done so out of legitimate concerns about sovereignty or economic opportunity or security ‚Äî that is, that they may have drawn rational conclusions and voted accordingly. 

3. Liberal cosmopolitanism has bought completely into its own rightness. It is entirely devoted to an increasingly borderless political future carefully managed by technocrats.. It sees no other alternative than that we will all, eventually, be "citizens of the world," and assumes that everyone will be happier that way.

4. It's not unreasonable to think otherwise. Anti-EU movements and renewed nationalism in the United States are on the rise precisely because they offer alternatives to this self-assured order. It's not clear whether a United Kingdom withdrawn from the EU will be better off. But it's entirely defensible to think that it might be. 

5. Likewise, it's not unreasonable to prefer loyalties rooted in close-knit interactions among people who share a particular space and a particular history. Or to prefer local rule to government outsourced to distant bureaucracies. Or to prefer a richer sense of belonging than interaction in a common market. There are alternatives to a transnational super-state that are not fascism. 

6. The inability of our political leaders to envision political futures other than the one to which they are wedded has facilitated the polarization, and the unresponsiveness, of our politics. That people are now looking for alternatives is, in fact, entirely reasonable.

Read more at: 

http://www2.nationalreview.com/article/437142/brexit-vote-racism-xenophobia-were-not-cause

The EU started its economic grouping with six European countries in 1951 and grew over the years to 28 today. It is apparent from the comments of politicians and the common people, that the EU has expanded numerically but its protocols have not kept up correspondingly. The expanded EU is too big to manage having to contend with divergent needs, and differing national imperatives. Not a few enlightened political leaders within the EU have called for an overhaul of the EU's operational structure and mechanisms to align with its members' needs and perceptions. It must be acknowledged that extraneous factors like immigration policies regarding immigrants from the Middle-east are not well received by citizens of member countries. The years ahead are going to be bumpy and whether the EU will emerge stronger or weaker is uncertain. What is certain now is that the global market has viewed Britain's exit from the EU as negative on balance in the short term. Hence, the British pound has depreciated to its lowest level in 30 years and the Euro also affected to a lesser degree. Stock markets around the world have similarly gone downwards losing 2.1 trillion dollars in a day. Everybody, not just the British people, have been affected. At the end of the day, it's not economics but mainly politics that drove 51.8% of UK voters to vote for Leave.

The immediate outcome of Britain's exit from EU, setting off a massive downward trajectory of the global financial markets have adversely affected not only the British people but practically all of us who live in our interconnected world.  A writer of an article wrote, "I just sent money to my kid, who's travelling over there‚Äîif I had just waited, I'd have saved a bundle now that the pound has collapsed."
Like the writer who was shocked and dismayed, many people the world over were similarly flabbergasted one way or another, taking losses because of the historic depreciation of the British pound amidst the global financial meltdown of Britain's unwelcome exit from the EU. That is the reality of the immediate aftermath of Brexit. The jury is still out on what will happen to the EU and UK five to ten years down the road. I hope that Britain will eventually rise up and be better off but that's just my wish.

We need to draw lessons from Brexit. Living in a globalised environment today, immigration is one of the many issues that most developed countries faced. Folks from less developed countries wants to move to well-developed countries. That's human nature. Didn't we start as a migrants' society and developed into what it is today as a multi religion, multi races, with diverse opinions and live as one harmonious society? This will only continue when people and government work as one. People need to be engaged. How civil servants does its work is how people perceive the performance of the government? Private sector professionals need to sit on public boards and/or committees to provide insights into the industry that civil service may not be entitled to based on their experience and training. Broad brush approached across industries should be avoided as each are unique to itself. Bond and trust will be strengthen when public and private takes ownership and the humility to admit that we do not have the perfect answers to all problems and to work together towards solving the problem and give recognition when it is due. We cannot shut ourselves from the inter-connected world, we cannot change the world but we can change how we view the matter, embrace the situation and work towards a balance that is best perceived by our people and best for the nation. If our jobs are so easily taken away by foreigners that is perceived as due to lower wage than locals. Shouldn't we reflect if we are competitive in the first place? Are we still adding value to the work place or nation before we rant? Challenges of any government in the world includes managing perceptions of the people, the choice of whether to have the courage to present tough choices to make or present populist policies by politicians. We need to continuously work on a culture and values system that is strong enough to withstand economic downturn, social disharmony and keep us United. Only with strong values system, will we be able to be tolerant with each other. The best gift we can give to next generation is the strong values we dearly hold and believe. In every society, every poor man or rich man has a vote. Singapore, being a tiny island do not any risk appetite to fail. It takes one vote, one moment to decide the future. It is the generations after who will shoulder what we decide today. It may take generations to correct a mistake from a vote. Engage, Empower and Balance.

The owner of the existing deployed capital base (Hotel) bought the robotics (Bed-making robots) with additional capital based on the considered recommendations of the managers - who then dev systems to train the workers to be more productive with the robotic capital. These managers have risked their social & career capital with their recommendations.

What is the share of productivity gained from the use of the new robotics between owner, manager and worker? The evidence is that in recent years on average all the productivity gains in the service industry has gone to the owner or to the managers of capital. 

Does the Union have a role to reshape this share? Can the Union act as a risk manager of career and social capital to recommend to the manager of deployed capital - better organization, methods and tools to obtain and distribute a larger share of the productivity gains either by robbing the managers of capital or the owners of the existing deployed capital to the mutual benefit of all? It may not be a zero sum game.

If the worker used SkillsCredit to fund their own training in the new workflow - can they have a larger share of the gains in productivity?

If the Union provided POC financing for a team of Union workers who voted for initiatives to improve their job design hence accelerating organizational adoption - can the Union and workers obtain a larger share of the productivity gains from the deployed base of capital as a basis of tripartite action? It is the traditional role of Unions to provide strike financing - Why not Work Improvement financing in order to obtain a rightful share of productivity gains from new capital injected?

Can you prevent the managers of capital belonging to the Unions from creaming the gains instead of sharing it more broadly using a socialist union culture alone? Can we re-shape the current productivity re-distributive formula by enabling more mid level/start-up managers to act as managers of capital w/o a new social org chart?

What underlies the performance of managerial skill in capital allocation?

How about removing phase 2A(1) for kids whose parents are alumni in elite primary schools, there is absolutely no justification in this. Already, a large factor of where people end up in life is determined by birth. There's no need to reinforce this further by assisting the 'elite' to cement their kids' futures by virtue of birth. This practice smacks of 'elitism' and goes against the very principle of meritocracy and encouraging social mobility.

http://thewireless.co.nz/articles/the-pencilsword-on-a-plate

"The pernicious spread of occupational licensing has stifled startups. Some 29% of professions, including hairstylists and most medical workers, require permits, up from 5% in the 1950s." - The Economist, The Problem with Profits, Mar26th 2016. 

IMHO, the possibility that occupational licensing could stifle startup is NOT a problem. The larger problem is that it supports ossification of client segments,  methods & processes. It stops agility and places the innovative cadence on the track of a WSQ committee. Who makes up & controls these committees? - the incumbent service providers more so that the clients for these services.

It makes for a less conducive business environment and makes it harder to build an an ecosystem that works because the selective pressures are external to the dynamics of demand/supply signaling. It is the incumbent lobbyist and professional beauty contestant/insider who wins in such business environments. That is NOT the way you build  an exceptional SINGAPORE. That is a nightmare that Skills Future 2.0 can bring without a nuanced implementation. If we do not put sufficient thought into refreshing & raising the substance of occupational licensing continuously, the unintended outcomes can be vicious and stable.

"The craftsmen hand-building cars at the Ford Motor Company's Piquette Avenue assembly plant in the first decade of the 20th century were, among other things, impressively productive at their tasks. 

Two or three workers would gather around each partially-assembled car, taking parts, checking their fit, adjusting them on a metal lathe as needed, then checking the fit again, and so on. To watch them work would be to watch experts practiced in their movements and efficient in their tool use.

But as we now know, this productivity was irrelevant, as their approach to the work as a whole was sub-optimal.

By the second decade of the twentieth century, Henry Ford perfected his assembly line model and combined it with a commitment to producing interchangeable parts.

This new workflow was less natural, required significant capital investment, and introduced many new logistical headaches: but it also unleashed a level of value production that the old method of car construction could never match ‚Äî no matter how skilled or efficient its practitioners." - Cal newport. 

Is there a solution, to make home ownership irrelevant to stability in home life for the middle class? Do they need to be driven into home ownership & asset appreciation prematurely & sub-optimally.

Should not the priority be to restore them to a contributory productive level and maintain a scaled efficient production & allocation of basic public housing. The asset appreciation logic is rent seeking is it not and not made easily available to the average person - let alone the poor & vulnerable? Where is the deeper point of leverage appropriate for a future more optimal Singapore?

"New ERP system 'will offer flexibility in charging'" in Today, 26th Feb 2016.

.

To justify spending S$556m, the main enhancement of the satellite ERP system must be in removing LTA's responsibility from fixing the ERP gantry charges by leaving it to the motorists to decide the charges and the level of congestion that they are prepared to live with and accept.

.

The satellite-tracking ERP real-time, interactive satellite-based system should allow for faster changes in ERP charges.

.

It should allow the motorists to decide among themselves the level of charges, and they should bear the consequences of gridlock traffic jams if they decide to manipulate the ERP charges far too low.

.

Surely, the system will self-adjust the charges as the top 30% high-usage drivers when affected by massive traffic jams would want to raise the charges for the following month to discourage the huge number of cars passing through that particular ERP gantry and time slot.

.

Also, LTA should use the system to incentivise and discourage motorists from using the CBD as a shortcut passage way to drive across the island during peak hours. This can be achieved by tracking the number of vehicles that take less than 15 minutes to cross the CBD from one end to the other.

.

However, many motorists are still not convinced that our COE and ERP systems are necessary in keeping our compact island of 713 sq km free of traffic gridlock situations. They must always remember that our CBD is in the southern edge and the reservoir catchment areas are in the middle of our tiny island of 5m people. All these fixed and unique features of our landscape affect the flow of traffic from one end of the island to the other.

.

Some Singaporeans even want the Govt to further control the vehicle population thus depriving many who are in need of owning a vehicle from owning one. We must not forget that vehicle ownership does not contribute to congestion, but overuse of vehicles does.

The ultimate aim in enhancing our traffic management is for MOT to end the dissatisfaction and scepticism in the public domain that the ERP system is inequitable, and that it is not for managing traffic flow but a revenue generating tool for the Govt. The new satellite system should make this happen.

Does SkillsFuture Credit qualifying rules pass the litmus test of weakening or strengthening individual ownership of skills? Does the implementation not surrender curation of an individual's skills road map to a higher mythical power or a skills bureaucracy? Is this surrender justified on the evidence?

Government funding will increase on continual education and training from about $600 million per year over the last five years, to an average of over $1 billion per year from now to 2020. This could be leveraging an increase diversion of SGD$10 billion in human hours on CET annually.

Are we diverting existing leisure or self-directed learning into unproductive CETs and a new unsustainable skills bureaucracy? - Is this counter-productive?

Will we be more effective having a billion $ bonfire each year on new years day to avoid wasting our citizens time listening to comparatively limited, outdated and unproductive courses? 

What is the control plan to weed out courses that do not add to the productive capability of our citizens? Will there be a positive ROI for the time away from leisure and family? How do we inculcate a discerning mindset with regards to information & knowledge? How to separate good intentions from the concerns of good logistical design of a sustainable system? How to discern fancy words like "partnering" from a real alignment of interests.

It surprised me that MCI and you, Mr Tharman, used the word "Federated" to describe the locker system out of the blue. 20 years ago, when I first mooted, patented and launched the system in Pasir Ris New Town with SingPost on a wireless data network used by taxis called dataroam- Federation was my & Sun's catch word. The system would allow for self-describing devices to join the network, self-describe their services to a controller/user in the cloud and offer a myriad of services and features at various locations. Today, protocols like REST APIs are firmly established standards for systems to programmatically communicate.

Instead of a single provider offering one type of locker, the system would be able to continuously evolve with various new designs and business models joining, leaving and iterating. So it pains me to say this. The fundamental user facing function has hardly evolved since the core founding team left 15 years ago. The system was developed as a prototype of a larger ideal - something that could evolve and be ever future ready. I hope that it does not continue to exists as a single narrow niche device it has stayed for the last 15 years. The system was manifested as a prototype for a specific investor & then market entry strategy to establish a location at the void deck. My handlers & mentors were not keen on federation and did not see the notion as a positive contributor. I lost the argument fair & square. 

The hardware designer is now Dy Head of the COE ATM PO @ CAAS, the software lead is now running software ops based outside of Singapore, other Alumni are in strategy, telcos, venture funds, unicorns & ATCs. I hope the notion of federated lockers & First Cube can really live up to the promise of FEDERATION & IoT that was the premise of its birth 20 years ago. Wow... a blast from the past.

One of many cultural strengths of American society is the role pervasive grassroots sports play in supporting an understanding of a team-based competitive bent in that individualistic society. Take the American football meme of a "3 day" offensive install. That is American football lingo for a large team of players to drill and learn a complex new play to game day competency. The coach "installs" the play he invented into the team in 3 days as a Standard Operating Procedure. Practices are executed in 15min takt times and expected to be efficient with the parents watching.

Likewise, the Japanese have cultural practices to support large scale efficient cooperative norms. The "andon cord" culture germinated in Japan and was then transplanted into the world. Firstly, it took root outside of Japan at the much studied Californian GM plant in the mid-1980s, and then to the Canadians and beyond. Many practices of the lean movement can be traced to these cooperative norms. 

Likewise, we too can count many cultural strengths. 

Yet, when a stalwart institution like SMRT fails, it is good that we pause to reflect. It has been many days since SMRT started failing. Do we need to consider how to do better and level up to a higher performing culture faster? How do we get there and what cultural or institutional norms are not helping and which are helpful? Is our gold standard in change management sourced from our Armed Forces? Should we revive the military tradition of a policy of fast relief in field commands to strengthen selective pressures on our institutional blueprints?

Would a trainee survive or be praised for pulling the andon cord in the current SMRT culture?

Does it have the smell of a bureaucratic institutional blueprint? 

Should we continue to invest in our best military experts, take the casualties, par for the course as canon fodder and move forward and accept the cognitive blindness by leaky military metaphor?

Today, I hope, the tragedy can make the realization of new adjacent possibilities more possible.

The growing list of red flags for SkillsFuture is worrying. I count the vagueness of objectives, the non-support of healthy, self organized  learning channels, the emphasis on credentialized monetized training. The lack of frank public evaluation of the WSQ program & ATO as a major plank of industrial transformation. 

Two examples are cited to warn about not grounding the SkillsFuture 2.0 concept in first principles of cultural change. 

In 1972, Gen Eli Zeira's "concept" & his firm hold on the Directorate of Miltary Intelligence cognitively blinded the Isreali Cabinet & Army General Staff . 

In the autumn of 1940, high-ranking German economists led by Gen Georg Thomas advised against an invasion of the Soviet Union stating that it would be an unbearable economic burden and the army logisticians further calculated a rate of advance would place Moscow beyond reach prior to a need for winter preparations. However, the "concept" not the grounded study of logistics held sway.

We all yearn for the good intentions for the concept for a mass Movement in skills cultivation - "What if... the major planks already implemented are flawed and will never support these goals but instead prevent their achievement? What is the current Bayesian probability of goal achievement" Remember Goal 2010. Remember SkillsFuture1.0

Does information goods about skills have the same economics as that of other public goods? What are the feedback loops when paid & gov credentialed "trade secrets" in WSQ displace transparent, open, trusted, highly reviewed free information on skills (Khan Acadamy, youtube channels) for time and attention? Hmmm... What happens to the misdirected cultural forces when Gov incorrectly identifies and confers prestige & shame on the wrong activity. How does the WSQ system select alternatives for learnability and how does this information about learnability get transmitted to the prospective learners? What type of institutional blueprint is going to succeed in supporting SkillsFuture 2.0 as a grassroots, societal wide & deeply impactful movement? - a civil service blueprint with its planning cadence, org chart, playbook & rock star management allied with a commerce-driven blueprint? - Like our diverse cohort of CET commercial schools, ATO & universities. Hmmm...a yet to be invented blueprint - altruistic, agile, open sourced & sensitive to the building of cultural norms and signals?

We have a well-resourced national library system - with beautiful classrooms & other teaching facilities- yet it was not deemed an appropriate institution to drive SkillsFuture 2.0. Why? I am mindful of the traditional institutional focus of our professional librarians but the mission clearly fits.

I am Cantonese. I remember my granny cook a very delicious "Cai" a vegetarian dish on Lunar New Year eve in the 50's. The dish is almost similar to Sir Shanmugaratnam description of the Nonya Chap Chye dish but Cantonese Cai add "Nam Yue" curds which give a distinct taste to Cai. I understand Cai was a vegetarian dish of Canton. After her passing my mother continue the tradition until she passed away in 2008. It was a dish that all my brothers, sister, nephews, nieces, relatives look forward to eat on New Year day when they visit us. I never learn to cook it during my mother's life time but did watch while I help her in her old age as she was weak and cannot stand up too long. I will cook Cai and other traditional dishes for my family gathering meals on New Year day from memories of my granny and mother cookings, but regrettably never been able yet to cooked the same due to the struggle with the little time I can spent with our elders to learn so much they have and not passed down.

Mr Chan Chun Sing, Mr Lim Swee Say, Mr Patrick, Mr Teo S.L.  - Can NTUC assist unemployed PMET and all Singaporeans by having them registering their names at specific unions representing specific group of workers. Example - bankers, IT , Shipping etc, etc, The specific unions will understand what companies and workers require, rather than present system WDA, E 21 are run by general staff who are not sure of the skills requirements. Companies looking for workers must approach these specific unions for specific candidates and same time publish in Jobs Bank . The specific unions will liaise with the companies and sent their specific candidates for interviews. Such simple exercise will prove if companies concerned are seriously in search for Singapore Core workers or simply die die looking for foreign talent. MOM and NTUC and TAFEP will then have a case to discuss with the HR of the company concerned should they constantly reject unemployed qualified Singaporeans. There are companies in Singapore where the HR are foreigners which should not be and in country like Indonesia, foreigners are not allowed to take up HR posts for the simple reason, they will bring in only foreign talent. Is time for change and not make speech after speech with no simple corrective actions been done

Otherwise I would suggest let us withdraw our CPF to feed ourselves as we are Senior Citizens and is wrong of you to make us beg for a living and been treated like 2nd class citizens, while foreign talent enjoy the fruits of our hard labour. My first job was 50 cents an hour as apprentice in Sembawang Shipyard in the 70s.
Un-employed Singaporeans are getting hungrier day by day and the figure is growing and is about time we see real actions taken by MOM, NTUC and TAFEP.
To allow foreign talent to continue coming in without any accountability to the people must be stopped

TS, saw you at the neighbourhood CNY celebration last night.. but I suppose you would rather be in shanghai.. felt sad that you are being kicked upstairs.. I suppose it is time to look for a meaningful role outside PAP.. after all, you have repaid your benefactor more than enough for saving your career after ISA. world bank president 2017?

There is a terrible price for PMETs to be paid for having a SkillsFuture program that does not work. I saw a Powershell course, costing $12k funded by SkillsFuture, that you could basically view for free online on youtube, based on a book that cost $60 that is available from NLB. This week, wednesday, there is even a microsoft hosted powershell clinic meetup costing $0. Is the premise of the program & organization design correct? We have wasted 10 years with SkillsFuture 1.0. Does SkillsFuture 2.0 have any fighting chance of success in its current form?

How do you know that SkillsFuture 2.0 is succeeding and the mechanisms are working? Have you established the surveillance & control plans and placed personal political will & emphasis on them? What is the primary curative pathway of SkillsFuture 2.0? Is this curative pathway well and truly established end-to-end or do you see only approximate proxies and a metric suite that is unrelentingly positive? - like the proverbial drunk who looks for his keys under the lamppost, instead of where he dropped them, because the light is better there.

What are the qualities of a workforce that enables a company to be more agile and respond faster and more appropriately to new methods & prospects? What are the pre-requisite conditions a company must create to foster and support these fragile uncommon qualities? What is missing from the current state of Singaporean SME managerial behavior and organization? Who & where are the SME doing it right in the world today? What are they doing and what is common that can be generalized? No SME can approximate google, facebook or netflix - who can be our role models? Is the Singapore Business Excellence Framework Certification Program an approximate answer? Can market & labor  rules foster & strengthen companies that can create better jobs? Do we know enough to trigger a sound policy response? The structured search for answers must continue...

How is Pongal day determined? Is there a fixed calendar day?
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thai_Pongal
Thanks for the link Vivek Durairaj. :)

It is essentially the same time each year, because it is based on when the sun begins its move northward (and spring begins) and the gregorian calendar of 365 days that we use is a solar calendar. Things get complicated for festivals based on the lunar calendar, which is 354 days.

While remembering David Bowie, dear sir, I would invite you to consider what Singapore is doing to its own David Bowies who embrace gender-fluid expression and unconventional identities. When they emerge in the arts we snatch their NAC grants away, we bury them in white petitions till they must run away to New York or Bowie's London. Government structures like the gender column on our identity cards or HDB allotments still operate in strict binaries and we do everything in our power to let our Bowies know that we believe only in blue and pink and not in stardust.

Ê∂àË¥πÁ®éÊ∂àË¥πË∞Å? Milking skin and bones....

Ever wondered why might any govt. favor an unequal society under a progressive tax system? 
Imagine $1 billion equally distributed among a population of 1 billion/ day ($1 billion / 1 billion/ day) --> each gets $1/ day. Now tell me, what could you possibly tax? Take into consideration, the emotional burden too. You earn $10 each day - how much are you willing to donate to charity? Suppose you earn $1,000. :)

So, they've come up with a consumption tax (sales tax/ VAT) such as the GST in which the poorer you are, the higher the likelihood that you will be skinned. Why? As consumers, we all consume, especially basic necessities. Applying a standard tax rate indiscriminately across all consumer goods and services - Sounds fair enough? 

But, take a closer look at it: The poorer you are, the less you can afford luxury consumption as a higher proportion of your income is already spent on basic necessities, while for the rich with a higher spending power, they probably still have income to spare, even after splurging on luxury items. The result? The poorer you are, the higher the proportion of your income is taxed under the consumption tax system. :)

While one might argue that giving tax breaks to the rich - who are willing to take calculated investment risks having been market-tested - encourages economic growth, does that mean serfdom is best for the economy? :)

There is a psychological effect. Annual income tax filing can be a hassle. The jaw-dropping amount taxed reminds you of daylight robbery. The pain and anger are sudden and unbearable. With the consumption tax however, it is a "boiling frog" scenario for most consumers. :)

Under a progressive tax system in which the govt. and rich share the spoils, the global community is already embarrassingly unequal. The introduction of a regressive consumption tax, more suitable for a wealthy society with a relatively fair wealth distribution, serves only to further aggravate an already widening rich-poor gap. 

Held hostage to corporate greed, the rich have shrewdly exploited intense competition among countries for foreign capital and investment to pressure governments around the world to downgrade corporate and income taxation, increasing the burden on poorer consumers instead to compensate the rich. Isn't this a double-whammy, for the lower-income groups? Is this sustainable, with the rich being the only winners? :)    

This is the inequality trap in a downward spiral - As the rich get richer, they wield greater influence. And the greater their influence, the stronger their bargaining power in negotiating ever expanding unjust deals for themselves.

SINGAPORE - The golden years are losing their lustre for a rising number of the elderly here, with more taking their lives in the later phase of life.

Last year (2014), 126 seniors aged 60 and above killed themselves. This is a jump of nearly 60 per cent from the 79 seniors who committed suicide in 2000. There were 95 of them in 2010.

While the suicide rate in Singapore has remained at between eight and 10 suicides per 100,000 residents over the past decade, the proportion of the elderly among those who take their lives each year has risen.Nearly 60% jump from figure in 2000; social isolation and physical and mental ill health may be contributing factors PUBLISHEDDEC 17, 2015, 5:00 AM  byJanice Tai

Just curious ...
By Judge See Kee Oon's standards
CHC Case - 6 years jail, 72 months of jail or 6*12*24=52560hrs hours of jail, ie $50,000,000/72 months = the exchange rate is 1 year of jail for $8,333,333 
Apply to Mobile Air Case -16599/50,000,000*52560=17.448 hours of jail = less than 1 day

By Judge Siva's standards
Mobile Air - 33 months of jail, ie 16599/33*12=the exchange rate 1yr of jail for $6036 
Apply to CHC Case - $50,000,000/$6036=8283 years of jail

Moral of the story, if you wana cheat, cheat big... There're economies of scale in cheating? Won't you wana cheat $50m and get 6yrs of Jail than cheat $16599 and get 33months, aka nearly 3 years?... Or make sure you get a lenient judge? Why are District Judge Siva Shanmugam and Judge See Kee Oon's standards so different? Maybe we should get the former to attend to the CHC case? More money involved $50m vs $16599, more people 30k paxs versus 26paxs, longer court case and more legal fees involved in former... Why isn't there some consistency in the "exchange rates"? The discrepancy in the rates is appalling! Do we need the Chief Justice to sit on both cases to have greater consistency in the application laws and penalties? Can you get your Law ministry to explain the drastic discrepancies to laymen like us? Thanks.

Dear Mr Tharman , first of all , I would like to congratulate the PAP on the beautiful victory on 11 sep 2015. Despite the unhappiness , I try to accept that it is for the betterment of Singapore and I voted for PAP. However, I would like to urge the PAP government to not take such votes for granted and to continue to listen to the people and engage people of all levels. Finally, I hope Mr Tharman can consider to be the next PM. 
I look forward to a even better 5 years under the PAP leadership.

Dear Sir ,  Dear PAP and Everyone, Why the PAP won big this GE,
TODAY reports: The People's Action Party romped home comfortably in most contests this General Election, representing widespread endorsement of the party that has governed Singapore since 1959. How do we explain this significant, unexpected result? SINGAPORE: GE2015 demonstrated the adaptability of the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and the resilience of the one-party system in Singapore. With their ballots, Singa¬≠poreans have handed the PAP a strong mandate. The outcome was unexpected, as the party romped home comfortably in most contests. The swing back to the PAP was across the board, representing widespread endorsement of the party, which has governed Singapore since 1959. How do we explain this significant, unexpected result?

First, given regional insecurities and economic uncertainty, a "flight to safety" mindset galvanised voters ‚Äî especially a significant middle ground of undecided ones ‚Äî who opted for the tried-and-tested PAP as the best way to deal with the real threats and those over the horizon. Prior to Polling Day, there was a pervasive sense of foreboding that the PAP may see further and deep decline in electoral support. While a freak election result was not deemed to be at play, voters probably felt that a further loss of political support would be highly challenging for the PAP with regard to how it would govern in its next five-year term. Second, the PAP has been working hard since the previous election in May 2011. There were enough hot-button issues, such as cost of living, public transport inadequacies, healthcare affordability, retirement adequacy and immigration. In pulling out all the stops to address these issues, which had caused voters to turn away from it in the 2011 election, the PAP demonstrated that it could rise to the occasion even with its back against the wall. Once again, the PAP's track record of delivering on its promises provided a safe harbour for voters seeking a trusted and tested brand.

Third, the Workers' Party (WP)-run Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC), which became the meme of the PAP's campaigns, caused voters in the PAP-WP match-ups to consider closely whether the WP measured up in the task of running a town council. This titanic struggle was about driving home the grand narratives of what AHPETC ultimately represented. For the PAP, AHPETC was about the WP's competence, character and integrity, as well as the imperative of honest and responsible politics in Singapore. The WP portrayed the AHPETC issue as representing all that is wrong with one-party dominance as well as the supposed bullying that comes with the concentration of power and the lack of checks and balances in the system of governance.

It is clear that the AHPETC issue seriously undermined the WP's electoral fortunes. In the final analysis, the PAP's narrative on the AHPETC issue prevailed and resonated better with voters. This was demonstrated in the WP's loss of support across the board ‚Äî even in its Hougang stronghold and the Aljunied crown jewel ‚Äî and in the PAP wresting back Punggol East.

HOW SINGAPORE IS GOVERNED WILL MATTER

The election outcome can also be explained through how voters regarded the relationship between two variables: One, the largest number of elected Opposition Members of Parliament between 2011 and this year; and two, the PAP government's significant policy changes and how it had engaged the electorate since the previous General Election.

Given the significant electoral swing-back to the PAP, voters clearly did not see the relationship as a causal one, despite the WP's claim otherwise. Voters saw the relationship as a mere correlation, and assessed that the PAP's policy changes and innovations, such as the Pioneer Generation Package and MediShield Life, the several rounds of property cooling measures, as well as the efforts to deal with the public transport crunch, were largely driven by the PAP's efforts to get things right. Singaporeans have used their votes to duly reward the PAP's conscientious attempts to assuage their unhappiness on these hot-button issues.

Fourth, this poll appears to have conferred a strategic advantage on the PAP. In essence, Singaporeans were in a positive mood after the climax of the Golden Jubilee celebrations, fully savouring the celebration, pride, unity and reflection. The massive outpouring of emotion at the death of founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew appears to have given the PAP an "LKY dividend", made more poignant given that Mr Lee Kuan Yew's birthday anniversary is on Sept 16. While one should not overstate the effect of the combination of the SG50 celebrations and Mr Lee's passing, it should not surprise us that the PAP's campaign sought to reinforce in the minds of voters the PAP's and the late Mr Lee's critical role in the growth and development of Singapore.

Fifth, regional and economic insecurities also contributed to the national swing to the PAP. The haze from Indonesia, which peaked on Cooling-off Day, was a stark reminder of Singapore's vulnerabilities. These potential threats also helped the PAP garner support, given its strong record in national and internal security, as well as foreign relations.

Sixth, although the PAP did not carry out a campaign of particular note, the Opposition parties did themselves no favours by seeking to be even more to the left than the PAP. They assailed voters with grand schemes of more expenditures on various things such as free healthcare and unemployment benefits. Ultimately, voters carefully considered how sustainable and purposeful such plans were and were not taken in by the political false prophets.

GE2015 did not provide a firm indication as to whether Singapore is moving away from the one-party-dominant to a two-party or multi-party political system. This time, voters did not seem to place weight on the WP's intrinsic value as the leading Opposition party and its role in Singapore's evolving political landscape, where the idea of one-party dominance is increasingly being challenged. Despite high expectations, the WP was not able to consolidate and build on its gains of seven elected seats. The PAP stymied and even rolled back the WP's gains and ascendancy. As for the non-WP opposition, GE2015 demonstrates that it risks becoming irrelevant in a more competitive and demanding political landscape. Singaporeans are firm that there should not be opposition for opposition's sake.

While an aberration globally, Singapore's one-party-dominant system, which has been in place since 1959, remains dynamic and robust. With their ballots, Singaporean voters are signalling that the PAP Government must govern with empathy and less haughtiness, and not lose the common-man touch. It is not merely about whether Singapore is well governed, but how it is governed that will matter increasingly in the years ahead.

The PAP still has lots of soul-searching to do. It has to grapple with its own instinctive quest for dominance, and balance that with the electorate's growing belief that political competition, diversity and contestation are critical ingredients in a society at the crossroads.

The battle for the hearts and minds of Singaporeans is now concluded. Now, it is time for Singaporeans to put aside their political affiliations and work together for a better future.

I posted this to both MND and ReachSg's site.  Can you look into this because what HDB has done is to contradict your much earlier statements about the affordability of HDB flats.  In addition, how could HDB  just forfeit someone's deposit ($1,000) just like that?!!! How many times has it been done already, that the public does not know about?  Can you look into this, please. Here's what I posted -

Can someone look into this. This family from Pulau Ubin was rejected from a HDB flat because their $1,000 income is too low. Not only that, their $1,000 deposit for the flat was subsequently forfeited. Is this true? If so, here are more questions for HDB, MND, and the MPs (I believe one of them is DPM Thaman) who said that having a salary of $1,000 is enough to qualify for HDB flats and that HDB flats are therefore 'affordable' for them. My questions are:-
1. How can their deposit be forfeited just like that? How many people's deposits have been forfeited already? Where does such forfeited money go to?
2. EXACTLY HOW MUCH do you have to earn to be qualified for HDB flats? Please come up with a definite answer, once and for all.
3. Has the criteria changed since DPM Thaman made the statements that with $1,000 income, you can 'afford' a HDB flat? If so, then HDB should have informed the Minister, or did they forget? Why create discrepancies like that, in the public's eye? 

Here is a quote from the article:
"...As it is getting harder for them on the bumboat rides, the family tried applying for a HDB flat. After paying a deposit of $1,000, their application was rejected because the family income was too low, at $1,300. As a result, their hard earned savings that formed the deposit was forfeited.

Wasn't it not too long ago that a prominent Minister of Singapore said Singaporeans who earn $1,000 could afford a HDB flat? If that is so, why has HDB defied the Minister's logic and turned down the family's application? Is there coordination between what Ministers say and how Ministries act or was the Minister's calculation a dud?

Moreover, if HDB thinks the family is too poor to afford a flat, why further burden them by forfeiting their deposit? $1000 is a lot of money, you can afford a flat with this amount, you know?..."

Here is the link: http://www.tremeritus.com/2015/10/17/no-flat-for-you/

I want to appeal to you to stop and review the SGX's Share Consolidation for Companies with share prices below 20 cents. Companies are consolidating 5 shares to 1, some companies even reduce your 100 shares to 1 share. This enforced policy will affect more than 200 companies and thousand of shareholders like myself and does little to nothing to the effect of preventing share manipulation. In a short span of a few weeks, small investors have lost up to half their investment, hard earned money and lifetime savings. These investors are middle class common-folks who cannot afford to invest in blue chip shares. As a direct impact of the share consolidation, investors now steer clear of shares priced at close to 20 cents. It is impossible for us to cash out at this stage since there are no buyers in the market. Moreover, the consolidated shares while currently listed at higher prices continue to dip and common-folk investors will only lose their hard earned money endlessly. 

I implore you to consider the dire consequences of this policy and take action to stop this. Singapore is a free market and we should work hard to keep our stock exchange in lined with that and leave the market to decide the share prices for itself. I look forward to your reply and action.

Dear Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam, this refuse truck is just too awesome. Would suggest that NEA look into this. 

To invest and import this machine in will be quite costly but attaching the crawl on the back of existing refuse truck would serve HDB estate with centralized bin centre and attaching it to the side just like what one see in the video will serve the private estate well. However, in long haul it will save on manpower as the cleaning industry just like any are facing manpower crunch.

Of course, the latest system using suction had been built for trial in Yuhua ward but there might be some problem in the long term of rubbish stuck mid way down the pipe. I know of some new condominiums using the suction system but they are experiencing major problems like stuck refuse mid way and pipe not properly attached back after the suction truck leave the estate causing leaks. And this type of system can't take more when maximum capacity is reached as it does not compressed rubbish.

https://www.facebook.com/thesiakapkeli/videos/1131133393576347/?pnref=story
Thanks, David. I have referred this to NEA to take a look. Best rgds, TS

Some Muslim shrines and mosques in Indonesia dating back to 8th-9th century and even Muslim shrines here in SG dating back to the year 1100-1200 are part of the testimony.

These ambassadors were the best scholars of their time and were from regions like India, Samarkand, Morocco, Egypt just to name a few.

These are just some of the part of history not made available in our schools or to our generation.

"... South America remained the main source of the limited amounts of latex rubber used during much of the 19th century. The trade was well protected and exporting seeds from Brazil was said to be a capital offense, although there was no law against it. 

Nevertheless, in 1876, Henry Wickham smuggled 70,000 Par√° rubber tree seeds from Brazil and delivered them to Kew Gardens, England. 

Only 2,400 of these germinated after which the seedlings were then sent to India, Ceylon (Sri Lanka), Indonesia, Singapore, and British Malaya. 

Malaya (now Peninsular Malaysia) was later to become the biggest producer of rubber. 

In the early 1900s, the Congo Free State in Africa was also a significant source of natural rubber latex, mostly gathered by forced labor. Liberia and Nigeria also started production of rubber.

In India, commercial cultivation of natural rubber was introduced by the British planters, although the experimental efforts to grow rubber on a commercial scale in India were initiated as early as 1873 at the Botanical Gardens, Calcutta. The first commercial Hevea plantations in India were established at Thattekadu in Kerala in 1902.

In Singapore and Malaya, commercial production of rubber was heavily promoted by Sir Henry Nicholas Ridley, who served as the first Scientific Director of the Singapore Botanic Gardens from 1888 to 1911. He distributed rubber seeds to many planters and developed the first technique for tapping trees for latex without causing serious harm to the tree.[5] Because of his very fervent promotion of this crop, he is popularly remembered by the nickname "Mad Ridley".[6]

I like DPM Tharman's eloquent ways of addressing Mr Stephen Sackur's questions. First, the DPM spoke on ethnic and social balance. The ethnic quota for housing flats, which was mooted by Dr Dhanabalan (I believe I remember correctly) and implemented some years ago serves to maintain the ethnic balance in housing precincts and neighbourhoods. Should this ethnic balance be upset, leading to the dominance of an ethnic enclave over the others in a certain housing neighbourhood, property prices would be affected in an undesirable way. Second, as our society evolves, we aim to achieve liberty - liberty in achieving our aspirations without being discriminated against because of our social backgrounds and other reasons; liberty to walk the streets freely and safely at night or at any time of the day (especially for women and children); liberty to express our viewpoints without the fear of suffering a backlash or being slapped, etc. We are a parliamentary democracy, but not in the British or American sense of the words. We don't have, and I suppose the Government does not condone, mass street protests, but we do have the Speaker's Corner and the Hong Lim Park in which political activists can voice their views and LGBT advocates can gather to light candles in support of their cause. The liberty that is allowed in our model of parliamentary democracy is not an unqualified one. People can exercise their liberty or freedom of speech within a certain defined boundary. Meaning so long as they do not infringe into others' sphere of privacy or hurt religious and racial feelings, or incite racial and religious resentments and cause social disharmony. In the past, magazines like "The Wall Street Journal" and "The Economist" had their publications temporarily suspended and their circulations cut down because of their articles and editorials which either slanted against the Government or threw untrue lights on our political system or economic management and policies. Authors like Catherine Lim who were given to literary excesses and who caricature the political leaders in unfavourable and satirical lights were rather harshly treated. But I reckon we have come a long way. The revolutions and development in social media means that it is no longer possible to curb or clip expressions of views in the same manners as were in the past. Anyone who contravenes the Sedition Act can be brought to justice or his/her knees. Singapore is a very small country, a dot in the ocean. A sesame seed. We have been able to forge a collective will, I think, in part also thanks to our spatial constraints. In other words, I think that precisely because we were small, or geographically limited, the Government's task of uniting the people of diverse ethnic and racial groups and backgrounds has been made light and easier. It is easier to forge a collective will within a smaller island country like Singapore than it is so for a geographically sparse and gigantic nation like America or England. As our pace of development gathers, we the Singaporeans will have to harness on our collective will and make it work to our advantage. Yes, no one owes us a living. Neither do we owe others anything at this point in time. The challenges ahead on our journey towards another more mature level of democracy are formidable. We don't have drastic debacles like the Authority crashing down on democracy advocates and supporters, like the infamous Tiananmen Square incident in 1989 in China. As the electorate becomes more sophisticated and discerning, a result of their high level of education, governance is no longer a task like building a tower or skyscraper. National leaders and policy makers will need to confront the reality of complexity in demands, differences in views and political preferences, resolving conflicts in opinions and forging a consensus. Our efforts in these, as in National Conversations, for example, are indicative of the steps that we have made forward, the milestones that we have achieved in our tenacious march towards a better and more ideal democratic system.

I used to live in Taman Jurong and spent many hours hanging on a hammock to read in this garden. One good way to improve on the nature is the gradual replacement of the vegetation with native species. Native vegetation are important because they provide the correct foods and living spaces for native animals. And, in the correct balance, neither leading to under-population or over-population of any particular species. Over-population of any particular species often result in them depleting the carrying capacity of their natural habitats, which then forces them to venture out to look for new living spaces. In essence, we must have a ecosystem approach.

Is the focus on specialist skills a reasonable & viable intervention point? Most vocational skills have such short shelf life that by the time it passes the politics of tripartism committee and makes it pass identification and codification... it is mostly irrelevant and the next skillset with premium pay is trending. The actual vocational skill is incidental and by-product to the meta-skills of skill acquisition and  continuous process improvement (aka lean/kaizen mindset). Does the current policy framework address the physics of skills lifescycle? IMHO, only for narrow low value-add segments. Can SkillsFuture move the needle? It is good to have more training, every advance country does it and yet I do not think the current institutions can do enough to be decisive. They will fail. The concrete physics of tripartism must work for the institutions to have a fighting chance.
