For people like myself, it is nice to hear of this as that is what learning ought to be. 

I guess I am the unlucky few: I was forced to learn English using the carrot and stick approach which did not work; not allowed to take Add Maths in secondary school that caused so much problems as I was made to study Engrg later in Uni; and later on in Uni when it was the time that Physics and Calculus was introduced to me, the learning environment was not conducive. I guess sadly to speak, I did not enjoy the style of teaching and did not gain much out of it. Not being able to get a Honours was regrettable, I did realised it was not entirely my fault as the system did expect people to have certain pre-requisite i.e. entering Engrg course in Uni.

Read up on Einstein learning journey, he did not let these external factor stop him from his learning or interest he wants to pursue. Never resent to external factor, is your life so everything is in your hand. If u don the pre-requisite, u have to put in double or triple effort to succeed.

Putting in doubles is one thing, but there are certain things that I guess it's best not for me to place it openly. 

What I can only say is there's a clear cut between delivering a lecture and having to double up. If no one is giving a good lecture, without a good direction on what to focus on it's useless.

Maybe I'll illustrate this the most. What is a lecture when it became lecturers starting to engage into mocking people (and they did not realise why) by comparing the levels of students with their children i.e. his daughter is better than us etc.

I was in that generation who was not allowed to take Add Maths, and suddenly overnight upon entering Uni, terms like hyperbolic cosine, sine and tangent was already expected to be known. The lecturers would simply use pre-requisite to seal off everyone's mouth.
We need to nurture all our students.

My own experience is that teachers typically pay most attention to both the best students and the weakest ones. To push them further or make sure they're not falling behind. ( If you don't belong to either, one good way to get some of the teacher's time is to come up with creative mistakes.) 

I mentioned this to a teacher who acknowledged that there's perhaps some truth in what I observed but who also went on to give me what I think is the best advice ever. That if something's worth learning, you should keep at it regardless of how little attention the teacher's giving you. And along the way, you'll also become tougher.

There was a split-thunderstom last night at around 11pm that lasted for a few minutes at our house.

We mentioned and felt that it could be the sign of a passing of a great man in Singapore, our former PM Mr Lee Kuan Yew.

He passed away some four hours later at 3.18am Monday morning.

Our former PM Mr Lee Kuan Yew made it passed Sunday by 3.18 hours. Great fighting willpower. 

The passing of a great statesman not only of Singapore but of the world.

The estimate on last Monday was that in his critical condition and last stage of his life, it would be a miracle for him to live pass midnight last night, Sunday. 

But he did. 

His struggle and strong willpower saw him lived 3.18 more hours. 

May his soul RIP. 

My condolences to his loved ones in their moment of loss and sorrow.

Our former PM Mr Lee Kuan Yew made it across into the 50th year, 2015, ....a total of 81 days and 3.18 hours.

Sadly he could not live a few more months to share in the joy of SG50 celebrations to commemorate his achievements under his leadership on 9th Aug this year.

He will watch the celebrations from the world of the unseen....

His spirit will be with us.
Great Visonary, Great Leader and roll model for future leaders. R.I.P

I share the grief and sorrow of all my fellow Singaporeans. Farewell, Mr Lee Kuan Yew. In each and every Singaporean who was born after 1959, lies a heartbeat that resonates your sterling legacy that you have built and left behind.

I am pretty sure no matter which Singaporean generation, there will be people who are really grateful and appreciative of what you have done and sacrificed for Singapore Mr Lee Kuan Yew.
Without you and your pioneer team stepping up, taking on all hardships despite of how volatile the political situations were in the past, and hanging in there while we were being belittled by some close to home country's leaders back then, you and your team proved them wrong and united Singaporean as one, regardless of race, transforming Singapore from a third world nation to the first world nation today. We Singaporeans can never repay you for what you have done, you are awesome and really impressive!
It's really upsetting that you couldn't make it to celebrate SG50 with us even though you are the main reason behind the rising of modern Singapore, a tiny little red dot island. You have done your best to give Singapore the vision back then to lead us to where we are today, let the next generation do our job and hopefully Singaporeans will not make wrongful shortsighted decisions that could possibly undermine what you had sacrificed to build in your lifetime. 
You have done a lot of great things for Singapore and even the world leaders are amazed with Singapore's accomplishments within such a short time and it's all because of you. You are and will always be the legendary founding father of modern Singapore for as long as we exist. My memories of Tukang (Or even the Chin Bee/ Quality Road area) as a kid was more of the food industries where I saw the labels pasted on the soya sauce or 3-in-1 instant coffee in my grandfather's provision shop.

I think the evolution of the Tukang area is indeed a testimont to the changing landscape of Singapore's industrial development.

That is my first place of work in 1969, it at Jln Tukang Tiga. It is a Japanese automotive battery manufacturing company. Salary is $3/day. Most of the workers are put up in dormitory. At that time most of the workers are from Malaysia.

Time are flying very fast and Tukang have also changed!!! we used to walk to and from work with a group of friends everyday. We will have breakfast and dinner at market 1. It use to be push cart stall and the price for a bowl noodles 30 cents, chicken rice 70 cents and char Siew rice 50 cents. Now all this are memory and are unblemished to go backwards. How beautiful if one day we are able to do it over again. Any Possible!!!!

DPM,  

Will Budget 2015 increase our cost of living?  

Budget 2015 has been hailed as progressive and inclusive as it aims to build our future and strengthen our social security. However, questions were also raised on: a) whether such budgets could be sustained, b) how they would be funded, and c) the risk of creating a crutched mentality.

The above are popular, politically correct questions. Perhaps, we should ask a more basic rhetorical question - Will Budget 2015 increase our cost of living? Actually, it already did immediately with the hike in petrol duty and added on cost by oil companies who took the cue from the Government. It is simplistic to say that the increase only affects motorists per se.

Through years of insidious public propaganda, ordinary citizens have been drilled to believe that Government subsidies, rebates, vouchers or grants, etc to help the poor will create a heavy financial burdens on tax payers and cannot be sustained in the long run, unless more and higher taxes are imposed. This is more apparent than real. The spectre of tax burden is not due to Government hand-outs by any measure. 

The costs of services and goods are always decided and inflated by the rich and powerful, but the burden of paying falls on everyone, and which are especially painful for the poor and powerless. In simple parlance, the rich become richer while the poor become poorer. Most of our current taxes have very broad-based multiplier effects, which burden the livelihood of ordinary citizens more than the rich. The financial woes of ordinary citizens are more due to the hyper inflated cost of living, and not their lack of efforts to earn enough to make ends meet. In fact, this has created a generation of new poor even among the middle or sandwiched class who were once considered well off and did not need Government hand-outs, but are now clamouring for more Government helps.

A good Government must be able to grow our national resources and reduce the tax burden on ordinary citizens. We do not need a government that keeps inflating costs of public goods and services, then hands out "generous" subsidies, rebates, vouchers or grants, seemingly to help, but in the next breath, insists that higher taxes are required to fund such social expenses. Such policies will only create the spectre of tax burden in a vicious cycle.   

DPM, in your post Budget 2015 TV forum, you called on all Singaporeans to come together and share the collective responsibilities in building a more progressive and inclusive society. Yes, your clarion call is irrefutable. However, if we really want to cultivate collective responsibilities and build such a society, elected leaders must start leading by example. They have the moral duty to lead, more so now than before, given that they are richly rewarded to do so. Simply advocating such an ideal is not enough.  

Best regards 
Lau Swee Kwong

Hello Tharman Shanmugaratnam,  Thanks very much for the skills future study award scheme. While the program seek to encourage greater take up of investments in technology and computer science, there are currently limited options for graduates to go back to school unless to enroll in a  full time 4 year degree course.  In the UK and US, there typically are masters courses in the field of computer science for students who do not have bachelor degrees in Computer Science. One example is that of Imperial in the UK. Most of the foreign universities also allow for students to enroll in individual classes in their universities as an open student?   However, It would appear that the only way students can take up a computer science course at a local University would be to take up a 4 year degree course at NUS/SUTD. Please will you consider either introducing a masters at our local Universities or allow students to sign up for individual classes as a open student at these Universities? They will make it a lot easier for people to pursue life long learning.  We need more flexibility in providing access to our university education.

Mr Shanmugaratnam. I was at De Anza's sister college - Foothill College, back in 1996, and the practice of lifelong learning has been has been promoted and embraced for a very long time. The oldest student during my time there was in his late 80s if I remember correctly. 

Cost of education is always a hot topic among Americans, and learning institutions have been trying their hardest to maintain affordability for their permanent residents. Back in 1996 when Foothill college was attempting to build up its popularity, Americans who lived in California were paying USD9 per unit, making a standard 3 unit course of study USD27 in total - healthcare and other administrative fees were minimal at worst, and they amount to about USD50 these days. 

Fast forward about 20 years down the road, Foothill College has grown in leaps and bounds, and current course fees for local residents have increased to USD31 per unit, no doubt due to rising costs and popularity of the school.

I believe that in order to promote lifelong learning, we need to create programs that are separate from the standard fare dished out at ITEs and the like, make these courses affordable for those who are in pursuit of knowledge beyond the workplace, and ensure that they run for a limited time. 

I personally believe that life isn't all about getting certified for a certain skill, and I hope Singaporeans will take a similar approach given time.

I too was considering making a switch to another industry, but the part-time course in Automotive Engineering would've taken me about 3 years to complete, together with thousands of dollars in tuition fees annually. 

It is unfortunate that I do not have the time, energy or financial capability to pursue such an endeavor, because I have commitments to my growing family.
But must ALL learning necessarily have an ECONOMIC value attached?

I was never looking for jobs around; I'm always thinking what I want to do, and "create" that job opportunity for myself, usually by learning a new skill and putting it to use in a very intern way.

In essence, if you believe you can always learn to take up a new career, your life will never be the same.

Community Colleges are not just for lifelong learning. It's a much cheaper route to completing a degree. See this article by Dr Jill Biden (wife of US Vice President) who had been teaching in community colleges for many years: http://www.forbes.com/2009/08/02/community-college-professor-higher-education-opinions-colleges-09-jill-biden.html 

Many top students in the US double enroll in community colleges in high school and enter college as a junior, taking 2 years to complete their bachelor degree. This is an example of a girl who did so and completed her medical degree (which is a graduate degree in the US) at age 21. At 23, she is a qualified Paediatrician  and she's married too). http://www.wesleyancollege.edu/profiles/courtneymitchell.cfm

Singapore used to have a community college (Broward College) run by CAE, which is accredited by the US regional accrediting agency. Students from the program had been able to transfer all their credits to accredited universities in the US, including the Ivies (eg Columbia U). Unfortunately, I understand that this program is no longer available. It's worthwhile looking at offering associate degrees in place of A levels in our JCs. The courses are more diverse and give the students a better idea as to what they want to do in universities, while allowing for substantial depth in the areas of their intended majors. About time we re-look at our present system of having students compete for entry into some of the more popular courses in universities (like law, business and accounting) based on their A levels results in subjects like maths, science and humanities, which are of little relevance to such courses.

It is indeed heartening to note many things or good initiatives found in the USA twenty five years ago or even earlier are now being implemented in Singapore or under consideration, eg besides this, we have facilities for the disavantaged, left turn on green etc. But can we shorten our time lag behind the advanced nations to say, ten years?

Peter Drucker is one of my favourite authors. And according to management guru Charles Handy, Drucker was '"probably the wisest of all".

Anyway, Drucker had high praises for the community colleges in America. Facebook was not founded in a community college. But I read somewhere that Mark Zuckerberg actually read Drucker to learn how to run Facebook. 

You know, if you read till the last part of the passage, when Drucker talks about why some "emerging countries(Singapore included?)" would still be decades behind America, I begin to understand why Charles Handy calls Peter Drucker "wise". 

**************************************************

(from Management Challenges for the 21st Century by Peter Drucker)

.....The United States is the only country that has actually developed this advantage‚Äîthrough its so far unique nationwide systems of community colleges. The community college was actually designed (beginning in the 1920s) to educate technologists who have both the needed theoretical knowledge and the manual skill. 

On this, I am convinced, rests both the still huge productivity advantage of the American economy and the‚Äîso far unique‚ÄîAmerican ability to create, almost overnight, new and different industries. Nothing quite like the American community college exists anywhere else so far. The famous Japanese school system produces either people prepared only for manual work or people prepared only for knowledge work. Only in the year 2003 is the first Japanese institution devoted to training technologists supposed to get started. Even more famous is the German apprenticeship system. Started in the 1830s, it was one of the main factors in Germany's becoming the world's leading manufacturer. But it focused‚Äîand still focuses‚Äîprimarily on manual skills and slights theoretical knowledge. It is thus in danger of becoming rapidly obsolete. But these other developed countries should be expected to catch up with the United States fairly fast. 

Other countries‚Äî"emerging ones" or "Third World" ones‚Äîare, however, likely to be decades behind‚Äîin part because educating technologists is expensive, in part because in these countries PEOPLE OF KNOWLEDGE STILL LOOK DOWN WITH DISDAIN, IF NOT CONTEMPT, ON WORKING WITH ONE'S HANDS. "THAT'S WHAT WE HAVE SERVANTS FOR," IS STILL THEIR PREVAILING ATTITUDE. 

**************************************************

For parents who think that hands are not important for cognitive and emotional development(among other things),  check out this book by a Stanford neurologist "The Hand: How Its Use Shapes the Brain, Language, and Human Culture". (http://www.amazon.com/The-Hand-Shapes-Language-Culture/dp/0679740473#).

We should not short-change ourselves, whether it is about developing the full potential of the Singapore economy, or ourselves as individuals.

American culture and history is all about change. 
The first thing we should ask ourselves is that are we efficient or being effective? EFFICIENCY is doing things right, EFFECTIVENESS is doing the right things. Just like there is a difference in between MANAGER and LEADERS.
I think we should understand the environment there, and the environment here are two very different equations with different dynamics and attributes.
There is a vast difference in their policy making and ours.
There is a vast difference in the mind set in terms of retirement, wages, benefits, HR policies and the list goes on and on..
There is a vast difference in cultural attributes for learning.
There are many difference our Country Singapore and the US.
And as most business strategically change from time to time they have done it from within.
And change occurs from a solid state to a liquid state and than solid again.
We dont change that way in our environment. We keep on multiplying, That is from a hard state we pour in softness that hardens and multiplies in size. Thus the size changes BUT the solid stuff is not soft to make the changes that is required.
Like I have stated at the beginning American culture and history is all about change, our culture is all about enhancement. In fact its not just our culture, that is facing the problem to change effectively, its the same problem that the whole of Europe even in Britain and Asia face. 
So the question is not if our people can change, the question should be, can our engine and machinery be change instead of having them enhanced or upgraded?
You need to change every part of the process not just the peoples mind set, but also the mind set of the business people, the government policies may it be HR or the benefits or even the recruitment and other things, instead of enhancement which is just tweaking the process bit by bit instead of a whole change?
The magic word is CHANGE not ENHANCEMENT.

The problem here is sometimes they still wants candidates with a certain minimum qualifications before being enrolled. I refer to "Large-scale clean-up operation after NDP" in Today, 11th August 2014.

I read it with much sadness filled with feeling of no national pride and shame that many people left behind rubbish for the cleaners at the floating platform after last Saturday's National Day Parade.    It is like having a perennial problem that we have no solution.  

In the book Hard Truths on the third page after page 354, there is the photo of :

"Lee hoses down Cheng Cheok Street as part of a week-long campaign in Nov 1959 to spring clean Singapore".

Many of us have forgotten Spring Cleaning Singapore.   Now with many foreigners in our midst, they do not know our concern why it is important to have a hygienic tiny and compact island state.  

The margin of error for healthy living condition is small for us.  Unlike a huge country, when an epidemic hits, we will not have much space to escape from it.

Do we need a week-long Spring Cleaning Singapore like in the 50s?   Rather, we need only an annual National CleanUp Day.

I hope the Govt will declare a NCD to remind all about how we started back in 1959 to clean up Singapore.  It will be a living legacy of MM Lee's foresight to have a clean and green nation.

It is to help all of us remember the momentous history and how we get out out of the ghetto to become what we are today. 

It is folly for us to take things for granted.  It is not given.

Next year, the 50th year of independence, is the right timing for us to have the NCD.

The NCD will not be like any other  anti-littering campaigns, which have proven to be less effective.

We want a clean Singapore not a cleaned Singapore.
R I P Zubir Said (1907-1987)

Yo TS.. This World Cup seems to be the most exciting World Cup tournament in recent memory, but I also lost a lot of money too.

While people in other countries are able to watch all, if not most, part of the tournament on free-to-air television in the comfort of their home, ordinary Singaporeans without pay TV, like myself, have to make their way to their community centres and McDonalds restaurants in the wee hours to view the TV broadcast. All this no thanks to SingTel winning the broadcast rights and charging an exorbitant subscription price for the event.

In many countries, major  sporting events, e.g. the World Cup and the Olympics, are required to be televised on free-to-air TV because they are considered events of public interest. For instance, pay-TV operators in UK are prevented from acquiring exclusive TV rights for such sporting events under the Ofcom regulations.

Will the PAP government consider such regulations so that ordinary people like me can enjoy simple pleasures in life without having to be held hostage by a government-owned monopoly? I can only count 5 to 10 more World Cup tournaments that I can watch before I report to Yama. :(

Finally, can I know why Taman Jurong CC is not showing?

DPM,  I think nursing is heading for a slow crisis.  My understanding is nurse recruitment numbers are declining,   number of students starting nursing as a first choice is dropping and attrition from active practice is not improving.  All in,  worrying for an era of aging and increased demand for healthcare services.
Mr Chua's excellent and motivation speech.

Hi DPM, the nursing role has evolved tremendously since the 1970s. Nursing entry in my seniors time, required interviews to allow assessment of that individual's ability to be a nurse. Nursing entry in my time(1990s), requires academic results, that do not need to be overly awesome. This has made nursing, a perceived 'easy' entry for all whole could not make it for the other courses. I belong to those who could not make it to the other courses. But I've since gotten my degree, and made my nursing my career, and my passion.

While it was easy to get into the course, passing the practical tests, going though the hospital attachments, handling patient lives, was no easy feat. This profession, is not for the faint hearted. 

I feel that efforts to improve nursing as a career, can be made better with allowing selected secondary school students to have a short stint in hospital, to observe how staff nurses perform in their jobs. This may be more effective than playing the current advertisements, which has limitations to truly show the public, our nurses. Individuals, whom finally decide to take up nursing, will not suffer reality shocks. 

I will like to also suggest that the nation recognises the passionate public nurses/healthcare professions regularly, by introducing nursing/healthcare awards (twice a year-currently once, and not well covered by media), and share with the public their contributions/sacrifices they have made to healthcare. Recognition, may help improve satisfaction level, and in turn, keep them in service. Agree with Dr Jeremy Lim, attrition rate is an area that needs to be addressed, as we need experienced nurses in the workforce to guide the juniors.

Audrey, thanks -  MOH will look into your suggestions - and together with MOE on student attachments.The National Nursing Taskforce has also made important recommendations to strengthen the profession. We will need more nurses across all care settings, including in the community and in the long term care sector. We will enhance nurses' roles and the value they can create in patient care, and must raise the attractiveness of the nursing career through stronger recognition and continuous professional development.

I hope the children of the lesser well off would eventually be able to move up the social ladder... at least somewhat better off than their parents. 

Having said this, I guess the education system has to evolve especially in today's world, with the intention of having a 40% cohort - university participation rate as I do understand and can feel that it's not easy for the children to move up since the parents can't help the children much as they move the education ladder. 

It's only in this uni course of study that I first learnt Physics, Calculus [more in details], Matrix, writing a report, conducting presentation, Econs as an elective [yes I've purchased the textbook for it and has kept it since on top of all the other textbook and with no intention of selling it away]. 

To think of it, learning how to speak up and be quick to find a respond to any discussion or even pre-empt it. I still remember having to find a solution when my professor [who happens to be sitting in the MRT COI] of giving an example of not learning mistakes of others... 

Poly days was more on technical knowledge on fields such as electrical, automation and materials [terms like fatigue and material failures]. 

I can't ask my dad for help over uni matters since he only had O level education, though I'm grateful that he's able to cover for my uni tutition fee and the related daily expenses in cash after all the years of working in my grandfather's provision shop and now trading shares.

Before I forget, the economy has to continue to evolve and restructure. In the recent NTU job fair, somewhat I got to hear from the companies HR stating that they're finding it difficult to employ poly fresh grads owing to everyone's aspiration to upgrade themselves with a degree... It's something that's potentially risky...

I don't think by increasing Medisave contribution and insurance coverage alone solve the problem of health care costs. To some extent, health insurance encourages over-consumption and rising health care costs. There is a need to address the issue of rising health care costs, not all of which are due to advancement in medical care and technology. Don't you think there should be some scrutiny on hospital charges when it amounts to $4.54 for a safety pin cost and $4.51 for an 8 oz foam cup, both before GST? That's easily more than 40 times what the item would cost. 
Let me provide 2 more examples: 1) A pack of gauze (individually wrapped) sells for $3 for a pack of 10 including GST at the pharmacy while the hospital charges $5.12 before GST for a pack of 6 (not individually wrapped). That's more than 3 times the price elsewhere. 2) An impatient is charged $10.60 a tablet for an antibiotic like Augmentin compared to $2.20 at a private specialist clinic, both unsubsidized and before GST. The difference is close to 5 times, though the hospital is likely going to have greater economy of scale compared to a private specialist clinic.
While hospitals are entitled to make a reasonable profit, the amount of mark-up is ridiculous and I would say unconscionable, bearing in mind that in healthcare, it's not exactly a free market as the patient do not have the option of buying those items elsewhere. If we allow such costs to be charged because it's covered by insurance, insurance premiums will rise astronomically in the years to come due to the claim experience. The often given excuse for the escalating health care costs is technological advancements, but I don't think that present the full picture. I've provided several examples which could partially explain why health care cost is so high. This is just the tip of the iceberg ‚Äì most of the time, the consumers are not in a position to know if they are overcharged or even if items charged had indeed been consumed by them. Such costs can and should be controlled to prevent unsustainable rise in health care costs and insurance premiums.

There should be a budget set aside to encourage youngsters to start their own business when they are in the early 20s. In the 60s to 70s, older generation took up entrepreneurship when they were young, with little education. Their organisation grew big when they were at their early 30s. Now, education takes up some time (e.g. 10 - 15 years) and most youngsters with full education (e.g  diploma or degree) only start their own business venture in their mid 30s with little saving. Some succeeded and some failed in their 30s. For those who succeed, their business only grow when they are 40s to 50s, which will not help Singapore economy to be vibrant in the short term. It does not allow them to be successful at the early age, which indirectly discourage them to have family and to have children early. Youngsters only start having family and children when their career stabilise. We should have more SME rather than MNC established in SG to keep our economy stable. In downturn, SME stays as SG is their home. MNC scale down and venture somewhere until it gets better again. Employment rate will be affected if we are too dependent on MNC.

Hi Sir. My parents are visiting from New York and I took them to Little India tonight for dinner. We had a great meal at Ghandi Restaurant on Chander Road, after which my father wanted a beer. The nearby unavailability, I assured him, was ultimately for our safety. My mother commented on the curiously high police and private security presence - again for our safety I confirmed. After an uncharacteristic silence, my father went into a strange retrospective of the Vietnam days in America, and how some young people stopped a "really bad thing" from continuing. I can't say I fully understand the connection, but it left me with a slightly unsettled feeling. As they went to their hotel in a taxi, I walked to the Little India MRT. That's where I saw you, handing out some small favors to people at the station. You had a big smile and a camera crew. That's when the unsettled feeling left me, and I too found myself smiling.

And he said:
Your children are not your children.
They are the sons and daughters of Life's longing for itself.
They come through you but not from you,
And though they are with you, yet they belong not to you.
You may give them your love but not your thoughts.
For they have their own thoughts.
You may house their bodies but not their souls,
For their souls dwell in the house of tomorrow, which you cannot visit, not even in your dreams.
You may strive to be like them, but seek not to make them like you.
For life goes not backward nor tarries with yesterday.
You are the bows from which your children as living arrows are sent forth.
The archer sees the mark upon the path of the infinite, and He bends you with His might that His arrows may go swift and far.
Let your bending in the archer's hand be for gladness;
For even as he loves the arrow that flies, so He loves also the bow that is stable.

Sir, I'm hoping that you can respond to what I've to share here. The rise in anti-foreign sentiment has been going on for some years now based on legitimate causes. However, what is alarming and unacceptable is the simultaneous rise in anti-Singaporean sentiment and behaviour among large numbers of foreigners in Singapore. It is perceived, especially online, that we are on our own and having to fend off discrimination without the help of the powers to be. A very recent viral video of a PRC man shouting death threats to a Singaporean in the MRT has not elicited any response from the police or any authority. Social tension is rising and our decades of nation-building is unravelling right us.

Before we reach the critical point, can I suggest the following measures to reduce the dangerously high foreign population with negligible effect on the foreign workforce. 1. A 5-year breather in new PRs/Citizens with the exception for those who have completed NS, offsprings of S'pore citizens overseas and 'strategic' individuals. First proposed by your PAP colleague, MP Inderjit Singh, this step will prevent their spouses, children, parents, parents-in-law and grandparents from settling here. It also gives us some much-needed time to at least partially integrate our new residents. 2. Suspend the dependent passes privileges of existing S-pass and E-pass holders. A concession can be granted to EP P1 holders who can continue to sponsor their spouse and children so as to sustain the international schools. 3. Suspend the long term passes for the controversial study mamas and student passes for private schools. 4. Reduce the unpopular scholarship cum living allowance for foreign students. This policy has the damaging effect on our students, who feel discriminated like 'non-bumiputras' versus the foreign students 'bumiputras'. Official development aid to Third World countries can be in the form of vocational training or infrastructual development in their home countries. These scholarships have caused unnecessary hurt and envy to our own.

Sir, I harbour no malice in seeking your response to the issues I have mentioned. Over the past few months, I've posted to a few ministers but to no avail. I sincerely hope you can be different this time. I have come to the realisation that regime change is unlikely in 2016 due to the advantages of the incumbency. Thus, I'm here as a local born and bred citizen seeking your help to avert a looming crisis in the only home I know. You see, I do not possess much wealth or talent to emigrate. I just hope we can contain the forces that threaten to tear our social fabric apart. Thank you.

Don't think we should just shut our doors and say "give me time to think". This is a dynamic world. Once we do that, we get an unwanted reputation that will stick for a long time and hurt us internationally. We should stay with calibrated steps than adopt extreme approaches. Don't forget that we now have many Singaporean sons and daughters with foreign spouses, and they hope to stay here permanently with their spouses. Many of these spouses are qualified individuals who may not fit the category of "strategic" individuals, but can work and contribute to Singapore's prosperity. This is certainly one group that can be assimilated into our society more easily.

The 'strategic individuals' are a concession in a spirit of compromise. You know there is a liking for billionaires and PRC athletes in high places. My comments are made in realpolitik terms, I have to appease in order to change the looming disaster.

Foreign spouses employed here are holding workpasses. Even if they are not working, they are here on long term visit/visit plus pass. This growing group is not covered in my suggestions as they have Singaporean spouses aka voters.

Sir, btw. I've noticed that ever since the banks began to jack up the transaction cost of handling coins over their counters, people have begun putting up notices indicating cessation of accepting 5 cents coins.

Coins are not legal tender to begin with for usage on bigger monetary transaction, so definitely people would want to find ways to reduce the amt of coins they keep.

Furthermore the banks seriously as I'll crudely put it, have sense of social responsibility over these matters.. They're only thinking of how to increase their ultra high profit level. I did saw the circular they sent to customers... They are now literally extorting people even with Legal tender transaction... $50 surcharge when the notes are not categorised during the transaction.

Anyway, I sense in future, as they further jack up such surcharge, sooner or later even 10c coins will find it difficult to be accepted. Then how on earth people are going to find 10 cents coins circulated to take bus rides if their ez-link card happens to be of low value?

To those urging for a reply w.r.t that article dated in 2011. I have one thing to say, its called: real-time governance. Our policy makers have the task of constantly gathering data around zones of economic need and social tension before they implement policies to empower our society. As such, there is an inherent need to make changes to policies as and when needed. 

For the ignorant: Singapore is a microcosm of the world's economy. Whatever that happens around the world affects us. Especially so when most of our revenue comes 'flowing in' . There is a need for us to be self-sufficient and at this point with so many calls for better healthcare and housing it is expected that our gov's expenditure may exceed its total revenue and there is till a certain time before our reserves run dry. Therefore, the self-sufficiency effort will have to be sustained by our people. 

Plus with the declining birth rates and an increasing aging population (who are usually not contributing to the tax revenue) - its only common sense that whoever is paying tax will have to absorb higher costs. From what I have read in the past 16 people absorbed the cost of taking care of 1 elderly, now its 4/5 is to 1 elderly and if its status quo it may become 2 tax-paying individuals to 1 elderly (numbers may not be accurate) - but the idea is we are and we will be seeing an inversion in the numbers...

Would you rather have increased individual income tax? Or perhaps 'force' the elderly to 'work till death' so they will be self-sufficient (that way the rest of us don't have need to pay for them)?

My current fear is that there is no productivity growth in the construction industry despite all the effort. Recent hike of foreign constructon workers' levy and restriction of foreign workers entry was a failure that simply caused inflated cost and longer construction time for completion. The contractors I spoke to all commented that NO PRODUCTIVITY GAIN will come out of these policies. They simply pass the cost and delays to the developers. Some contractors with committed projects at old prices have already gone bankrupt because of this hike in levy. So how can we improve productivity? We need to help a few subcontractos in each trade improve their methods, technology and management skills. We need to eliminate those wasteful practices on jobsites which the maincons create to pass risk and cost to the subcons. When some are more competitive than others, that's when the competition begins. Raising the levy simply create a new expesnive level playing field. That is definitely not working today. LKY's latest book says that if you remove the foreign workers, the SMEs will collapse. He also said the reason of the current policy to restrict foreign workers is a political one due to public pressures. I felt that Singapore govt has always valued long term perspective. To buckle under pressure and do knee-jerk policy on the construction industry should not be their style.

"Fearlessness may be a gift, but perhaps most precious is the courage acquired through endeavor, courage that comes from cultivating the habit of refusing to let fear dictate one's actions, courage that could be described as 'grace under pressure' ‚Äî grace which is renewed repeatedly in the face of harsh, unremitting pressure.
Within a system which denies the existence of basic human rights, fear tends to be the order of the day. Fear of imprisonment, fear of torture, fear of death, fear of losing friends, family, property or means of livelihood, fear of poverty, fear of isolation, fear of failure. A most insidious form of fear is that which masquerades as common sense or even wisdom, condemning as foolish, reckless, insignificant or futile the small, daily acts of courage which help to preserve man's self-respect and inherent human dignity. It is not easy for a people conditioned by fear under the iron rule of the principle that might is right to free themselves from the enervating miasma of fear. Yet even under the most crushing state machinery courage rises up again and again, for fear is not the natural state of civilized man."
- Aung San Suu Kyi

Dear Sir, it is with a heavy heart of empathy with my fellow Singaporeans who are discriminated against in their own country. From my own observation online & offline, our society is in the early stages of disintegration. May I suggest the following for your consideration: No foreigners shld work as employment consultants due to its socially sensitive nature. We have to roll back some of our Work, live, play & study for foreigners. Remove dependent pass privileges for EP Q1, P2 & S pass ($3K or more) holders. Freeze on all other DPs except those born in SG. No more new/renewal of Personalised EP, study mama & student pass for pte educators. Increase maid levy for non-citizens except those with young children, elderly & disabled. A temporal halt in new PRs & citizens except those who complete NS or children of SG citizens born overseas or a small no.of strategic investors. Some of these measures will increase the foreign labour participation rate while decreasing or at least maintaining the foreign population.

Hello sir, very happy to read this post and the article. For providing equal meritocracy the society is still not ready, more thoughts and education like this from a primary level should help sow the seeds in the minds of the growing generation.

The Government can play a part too by not giving scholars/young admin officers an instant head-start? Practices may have changed since I was working in the public service as a young(ish) civil servant. MAS was an example of good practice, from my own personal experience (as a non-scholar). It did not put its scholars on a pedestal, they were ranked together with their peers, and competed for promotions on an equal basis. I was impressed. On the other hand, personally I found the practices at MOF (the parent ministry) more rigid ...

Embracing meritocracy is all well and good. But meritocracy alone doesn't mean we have the right people in the right vocations, if the slew of cases against government servants has been any guide. We need to recognize that people are capable of bigger things, with or without a certificate. How many late bloomers have we seen? Autistic students, people from less privileged backgrounds who have striven against the odds? No job is lesser than the other. We even segregate people based on their vocation; blue-collared, white collared, which automatically compartmentalizes our attitudes and mindsets towards them. We need to be able to reward construction workers and cleaners with higher wages, like those in Scandinavian countries. We need to be able to live in a society where children are encouraged, no matter what profession they choose and not just glorify certain professions. Not everyone will be a doctor or a lawyer. We need to be able to recognize people as people and not by their vocation. We're in this, together.

I like the word "Mastery", in a game we have to be very experience in a very specific skills in order to earn this badge. The more mastery we have the faster we can level up in the game. Mastery is the key, this is a fine tune between skill, experience and knowledge and eventually wisdom. we should be able to dance with problems when we have mastery. Cheers sir!

It is refreshing and uplifting to read the interview, like rain after a long draught. I have high respect for Tharman since my days at MAS. Lets hope Singapore practices the kind of meritocracy envisioned in the intreview. It will change Singapore for the better: united,  prosperous and advanced.

We may delude ourselves to think that we have a meritocratic scholarship system in Singapore but there are elitist schools amongst us (read ACS, RGS, RI, Nan Yang Primary School, etc) and the highly sought after tuition centers which only the rich can afford (The Learning Lab to name one).....the ever insightful Ngiam Tong Dow has this to say: "Paradoxically, this income divide is seeded in our deep belief in meritocracy. In the past, equal opportunities in education have provided the social mobility to enable the bright boy from a poor family to make good. The playing field was level for all students.

The spread of private tuition has changed the educational playing field. During my school days, only the academically weak students of rich parents take remedial tuition. Taking private tuition was not a badge of honour. Today, any parent who can afford the fees will send their children not for remedial but enhancement classes to give their children a head-start over their classmates.

Though there will still be the exceptional individual who triumphs against all odds, more and more of our state scholars will come from upper, middle income families with professional parents. There is no easy answer to the problem of an uneven playing field in our schools. In itself, private tuition is unalloyed free enterprise which society should encourage, not frown upon.

The challenge is to level up, not to level down. One suggestion I have is to make classes for academically weaker children smaller. The student-teacher ratio should be more favourable than in brighter classes so that the teacher can give more personal attention to each student, which is what private tuition is all about."

First off, I'm not sure we're all in agreement as to what we mean when we talk about meritocracy.  If meritocracy means an obsession with quantification, test-scoring, and qualifications, then there is really nothing inherently meritorious about meritocracy. If it's about giving individuals opportunities based on merit, that's fine. But it's not fine if academic credentials (or other irrelevant criteria such as performance in sports or mother tongue for an opportunity that has nothing to do with such achievement) are the only objective measure of merit.
Hierarchy is not just based on what happened to you at age 18. It happened even earlier ‚Äì at 9 (for the GEP screening) and 12 (for the PSLE which determine not just which secondary school, but also which JC you go to), and if you didn't make it, again at 16 or 17. These days, with the cut-off for the top JC at less than 3 points, it's not possible for any student going through the O level route to get in even with the best possible academic results (ie 6 A1s) if they do not also have bonus points from CCA or HMT. And there is a huge difference in terms of opportunities available to those from the top JCs and those from the others eg information and help in scholarship or college applications. How many scholars do we have that are not from the top JCs? And how many from the more popular courses in our local universities are not from the top JCs? How many who are not from the top JCs made it to Oxbridge or the Ivies?
 I do not agree that the US is not meritocratic enough in the school system, compared to us. It is true that their public schools may not be in the best of shape, but I've known of many from disadvantaged background who made it through to good universities, some with scholarships. Actually, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev is one of them. Many of their public universities are ranked amongst the best in the world, ahead of their private colleges or even some of the Ivies. On the other hand, it is a lot more difficult for someone from a neighborhood school to make it to the more popular courses in our local universities these days, compared to 20 years ago. Those who are not strong in the sciences or humanities are disadvantaged up to JC and don't stand much of a chance even if they're applying for courses in a totally different area eg law, business, and accounting. 
How good a school is is very much dependent on the type of students it has. Well, all our schools are good schools. But there are better schools where we don't find students smoking or engaging in certain behavior while in their school uniforms. And I doubt the good schools (especially at secondary level) are good enough for the children of the ministers. These good schools are no better than the US public schools. If that mean they're not meritocratic enough in their school system, the same goes for us. You may say that entry into our secondary school is by merit. But it is not. There are schools that take in students from their affiliated primary school regardless of grades, or at a much lower cut-off.  The other difference is that families who can afford to pay send their children to private schools in the US, while those in Singapore send them to expensive tuition classes.
Scholarship is a major impediment to meritocracy. A scholar is given a job (since he is bonded) even though he may not be as qualified as another person applying for the job.

hi Mr Tharman Sir, I read with interest many of the articles on straits times 'Ask DPM Tharman special' and articles here. I very much agree with the many view points. 

I once posted in a forum blurb an analogy such that if we imagine Singapore to be a v tiny island where 4 person is ok, 5 persons is a little crowded and with the 6th person is almost standing in the sea. 

it is inevitable that a somewhat socialist (to an extend in a light of Keynesian economics) would be helpful to the lower income group, i.e. for the richer among the 6 to help the poorest a little (note however there is an issue of moral hazard which its own topic, won't delve into it here.)

however, then the rest of the lot (lets say the middle income group) become the *sandwich class* since the above policies would basically be zero sum games, someone's gains is another's losses or benefits today may become higher taxes in future (this is basically similar to borrowing & spending and ending up needing to payback large sums with interest later)

i.e. the *sandwich class* are unlikely to benefit from many of the zero sum games policies and would possibly  appreciate the govt's efforts less since they're after all not the benefactors and perhaps even net contributors in the policies

hence the article "Economy: look overseas, firms and workers told" makes a lot of sense as that's probably the only way to grow a bigger cake for every 1 in singapore & growing the local economy.

but this is 'hard' from different perspectives, e.g. it requires a lot of *skills* and *knowledge* of how to do it to prosper from the regional and global economy, perhaps it helps through public education, govt linked efforts e.g. in some countries IT and such businesses push for GDCs (global development centers, global / regional shared service centers) etc, for high end manufacturing (pharmaceuticals), for financial services e.g. hedge/mutual funds, insurance, etc to be centered in singapore etc, for global internet firms (e.g. like facebook, google) in scale to grow out of and be based in singapore etc, but these ventures won't be easy to setup & grow without some kind of backing and skills injection. not to mention that as other countries are involved we may even see some trade friction, protectionism. 

of course, the other v common option is for a portion of singapore to travel and work overseas as well, e.g. setting up overseas subsidiaries

last but not least, going beyond the dot involves an element of *business risk* which needs to be managed well
We need more of u, that touch with the ground.

while meritocracy is generally good and is possibly a good way to move most forward, there is a trend in that 'meritocracy' is abused as a *front* by people who are in positions of influence to declare that their achievements are due to 'meritocracy' e.g. for bankers, traders to demand / pay themselves 10s of millions of bonuses on the basis that i deserve the 10s of millions of bonuses as i've created the wealth concept (the fact that perhaps luck and the fact that they bet the farm e.g. bet the entire bank's and including all depositors assets in the market  (this amounts to a large leverage) and got lucky is often never mentioned.

This story on Yahoo does not gel well with your call for a dominant PAP and not domineering. Its when the rubber meets the road that you can tell what is real. Perhaps you can explain how you can achieve what you said.                               In a Facebook post Tuesday morning, Nizam clarified that his pull-out reinforces how he is not seeking "political mileage" after deciding to drop his position at the Malay/Muslim self-help group and speak at the upcoming protests instead.

As Nizam rubbished suggestions he was using AMP for political gains, he said he is in favour of a strong civil society and diverse views for Singapore to be resilient.

"This will also allow my family and I to take a step back and have some quiet time on May Day for us to heal and to restrengthen our bonds," said Nizam.]

The charitable organisation from which a Muslim civil society leader resigned as director over alleged government efforts to stifle his airing of critical views declined to make further comment on the issue.

A spokesperson for the Association of Muslim Professionals (AMP) instead referred Yahoo! Singapore to a statement made on Tuesday by AMP chairman Azmoon Ahmad.

In the statement, Azmoon clarified that Nizam Ismail quit the organisation "to avoid further misperception" that his activities were linked to AMP's stand on political and civil society issues.

Azmoon also said that suggestions of external parties influencing his or the AMP board's decisions are "inaccurate".

"AMP holds closely to our core principles of independence, non-partisanship and critical collaboration with all parties that share our mission in the community, including other Malay/Muslim organisations, non-Malay/Muslim organisations, national bodies and agencies, and the government," said Azmoon.

In a post on his personal blog Wednesday, Nizam Ismail explained why he decided to quit as board director of the AMP and chairman of the Centre for Research on Islamic and Malay Affairs (RIMA) effective earlier that Monday.

Nizam said that AMP chairman Azmoon Ahmad called him on Saturday to say that he received separate phone calls from two government ministers expressing concern over Nizam's participation as a speaker at next week's May Day protest at Hong Lim Park.

The protest, organised by Gilbert Goh of transitioning,org, is to be a follow-up to an earlier protest criticising the Singapore government's top range projection of a 6.9 million population by 2030.

The ministers were also said to be concerned about Nizam's participation as a panelist at a Youth Wing Youthquake Seminar for the opposition Workers' Party and his critical leanings on social media.

Azmoon relayed a message that Nizam should "take it easy" and decline participation from such activities, or else, the government would withdraw all funding from AMP.

Nizam said that Azmoon suggested Nizam "disassociate" himself from AMP if he were to continue with the activities.

Saying he was appalled by the alleged threats of withdrawal of funding from AMP on account of activities he had done in his "personal capacity", Nizam deplored what appeared to be "political reasons" behind them.

"I could not, as a matter of principle, see myself functioning as an activist in AMP or RIMA's Board in an imposed non-critical state, in return for continued funding of AMP's programs," Nizam said of his decision to resign from the two organisations.

Nizam also alleged that the latest incident was not the only attempt at influencing AMP, which was established in 1991 as a non-partisan group to help Malays and Muslims in Singapore.

State funding of AMP's programs were cut in the wake of a proposal in 2000 for a collective community leadership and threats of funding cuts were also made in reaction to a the group's proposal in 2012 for an independent Community Forum, Nizam claimed.

"The readiness to use the threat of withdrawal of funding when the State feels displeased or threatened also ignores this important fact ‚Äì that these funds are being used to fund programs which benefit thousands of beneficiaries ‚Äì be they low-income families, youths at risks, [and] students," he said.

"The interests of these beneficiaries seem to be readily steamrolled," he added.

As of Thursday evening, Nizam's name had been removed from the AMP's board of directors' page on the organisation's website though his profile page was still live. His name had also been removed from RIMA's page.

In reply to the matter, Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs Yaacob Ibrahim said to Berita Harian that the government does not interfere with the internal affairs of Malay/Muslim organisations. However, he stressed that government help should not be used to fund political motives.

"What is clear from the comments made from Nizam is his wish to be more politically-active. The government considers AMP as an important Malay/Muslim self-help group like Mendaki, and offers assistance to help AMP handle social and education issues in our community. However, this assistance should not be used to aid political activities or self-help groups to carry out political agendas," said Yaacob.

Marianne, please be assured - CPF funds are completely safe. You can refer to this website clarifying various questions (see Q19) on our reserves and the CPF. The CPF Minimum Sum policy is entirely independent of our reserves. We inherited an unusual provident fund system from the British, in which originally everyone could take their money out at 55. Few countries have anything similar, and the UK changed their own system many years ago. In most countries, no money is taken out at 55, and one instead gets an annuity-like payment like under the CPF Life Scheme. Even then, in many developed countries, the social security system is now approaching insolvency. Our CPF is totally secure. We have revised it in steps over the years, and even today it is different from most other systems because one can  take out a fair amount of money at 55 based on a housing pledge. Whatever we do to refine the scheme must aim at serving members' interests in old age, especially as Singaporeans are living much longer now, fortunately. Best rgds, TS

Some households have a few income earners albeit low or middle income and smaller type of property thereby per capita household income is high whereas another household can have a bigger property (multi generation in it) solely having one or two income earners in d middle income level yet d per capita is lower for there are young children/elderly/disabled who aren't income earners to contribute to the household income. Rebates/credits for the young ones can only be realized wen they are of nursery/childcare goin age with the proposed budget, what about the age prior to childcare and post childcare? According to Ms Zheng Meishan, Exec Land Adm Manager - HDB, our beloved Minister Mr K Shanmugam and MP Dr Muhammad Faishal have a meeting with HDB personnel in late Dec 12/ early Jan 13 regarding the delay and a further meeting with Dr Faishal on 18 Jan 2013. Many residents have called HDB officers throughout last year and even written to both the MP - Dr Faishal and HDB more than a month ago since mid-January 2013 but no direct answers to the above delay in their multiple replies till this moment. We have even written our agony on the Facebook of Minister of National Development, Mr Khaw Boon Wan over a month ago with the MND Facebook admin acknowledgement but till date no reply! 

 To strengthen my point as Singaporeans, this delay of over one and a half year before the open tender for the above plot of land result in the loss of millions of dollars as HDB vacant those shop units over a year earlier eg with 30 shop units - premier location surronding Yishun bus interchange of monthly rent of say $9000 over 12 months (excluding coffee shops rental which are very much higher) - loss of over $3 millions revenue for government fund! If including the coffeeshops rental it can easily exceed over $5 million! Isn't the CEO of HDB and related planning officers accountable? As millions of Singaporeans are yearly income taxpayers or daily gst payers and some paying yearly property tax which increase this year (from no payment of property tax for 3 room flat in the past to paying ~$44 for 2013), we have the right to know. So a further delay by HDB will not be good for the residents and non-residents likewise as it will 'worsen' the '5 years plan for Nee Soon GRC' under the well-loved leadership of Mr K Shanmugam. Tan Kin Lian concluded that the root cause for the high cost of doing business in Singapore is GST.  He don't like budget 2013. He felt that it is quite wasteful.  Do You agree? 

Tan Kin Lian
I don't like Budget 2013. I also don't like past years' Budgets. 

Although the Finance Minister is quite generous in giving GST vouchers, productivity and innovation credits and the wage subsidy, it is a wasteful approach. 

It is better to address the root cause of the high costs of living and the high cost of doing business. The approach that I prefer is to reduce or totally remove the GST.

The 40% co-funding of the increase in wages can backfire. How to determine the increase for new employees? If new employees are not counted, the employer can recruit new employees at a low salary and give a big increase after a few months, to qualify for the subsidy.

We can expect things to get quite messy. Maybe, the Finance Ministry will find out some ways to prevent the abuse and the uncertainty, but the underlying approach is probably wrong.

"We are no longer a developing economy, but we have not achieved the level of productivity and income of an advanced economy." - How do we increase our productivity if we continue to take in those with degrees from third rate universities in third rate countries as professionals? I've heard of how engineers from Philippines and India working on out infrastructure projects cannot even read drawings because they do not even have any concept of proportion / ratio, something which our kids learned in primary school. If we want to increase our productivity, we should be taking in professionals with good track records from the advanced economy so that our managers can learn from them and level up, instead of those who are much worse than what we have and get a job here because they are cheaper.

i would like to see the various govt agencies working together to solve issues together. taking the revamp for the purchase of cars for example. if i'm not mistaken, it is to curb the rising price of cars as well as to help reduce the total number of vehicles on the road. work with LTA for a more comprehensive plan on how to tackle the issues

traffic congestion is not just due to the raw number of vehicles. road planning and enforcement also play a role. as what i can see from my commutes, a part of the congestion is due to the inefficient use of vehicular lanes. for example, a heavy truck at 50kmh occupies lane 4. a smaller truck moving at 60 kmh overtakes the truck but doesnt move back to lane 4 as the driver doesnt want the hassle overtaking and stays on lane 3. now a private bus driver in a hurry overtakes them both on lane 2 and refuse to move back into lane 3. this leads to a van, which is speeding at 85 kmh, to use lane 1. there could be a little more enforcement in this area to ensure smooth traffic flow. this difference of speeds also raises the chance of accidents

we also need to look at COE itself. at present it is a "who has $$$ who gets it" system. yes it does filter out those who do not have a need for a vehicle and yet buy one but it also puts the vehicle out of reach of a family that needs it. the new revamp to vehicle loan rules seems to have such an effect as well. maybe the different agencies should work together and implement a fairer way of distributing the COEs. allow families buying a car to ferry their 3 kids and 2 aged parents to submit documents for review so they can purchase a car. set aside a certain percentage of COEs for this purpose. have background checks on the registered address of the purchaser. should there be already multiple cars registered at the same address, a premium can then be placed. this would make more families to pool their resources together. as to the loan amount and loan period, similar plans could be made ie increasing the loan sum or loan period, for the people that need a car. of course, some may question the definition of "need", which could be subjective

as others have already raised, the public transport system really need massive improvements. try bringing 3 children to the beach on a weekend. i will not comment on the graciousness of the commuters but just focus on the difficulty of 2 adults handlng 3 children who may be running about or screaming or crying. even with my current 1 child, i was embarrassed when she started crying on the train as i felt i was disturbing the other commuters. should i try hire a cab when i'm going out with my parents, i could only wait for the 6/7 seaters as the normal cabs will not pick up 5 adults and a child

in summary, i would like a concerted effort in rolling out measures rather than a stop gap kind of approach by individual agencies. it just seems very unproductive

Jack Lin, yes really. Inflation will reduce savings value provided you have surplus to keep as savings. I studied Accounting so I know the difference between a depreciating asset and an investment. To avoid the 24% interest on CC that is why I pay my CC bills in full. Y to hv CCs? to utilize 0% instalment plans for household puchases like refrigerator, washing machine, fans, etc since I cant afford a lumpsum. Of your question of rushing in to buy a car. I am not in a rush for my Toyota car still hv 4 more years to go. But I know how families like me will feel with the newly implemented COE policies. U mentioned 'in the past' you used to take your grandparents on the bus, will you do the same with our current bus situations? With age, you will experience greatly reduced agility and strength and vision (does not mean you cant walked, cant see). Young kids have yet to be independent to take public transport on their own. Handicap person in a pack train/bus, do spend time observing if you find many of them on public transport in SG. It is not because they are pampered or not daring enough, but our strained transport systems dont have room for them (indeed many able bodied persons too find it a challenge to take public transport these days). With the increasing singles population in SG, why should Aunties and Uncles be excluded if you are their guardian/responsible for their well-being (provided they dont have their own car)?  I admit it is cheaper to take cab, take for instance my family, for my family to move about, we will have to take 2 cabs, will that be cheaper for me then ? D roads are congested because many people have cars since they can afford to pay for d convenience (luxury). But for families at certain per capita income, especially with handicapped and elderly parents, it becomes a necessity instead of a luxury. I admit there would be admin/paperwork involved to implement my suggested COE rebate scheme, but it is doable. What makes it cumbersome to implement is if like you mentioned, after kids grow big, pay back d rebates. I dun recall the govt paying back my parents fine NOW for having me, a 3rd child then, perhaps that too was too cumbersome for d govt.

Dear Sir,I must admit I do not have the expertise or knowledge to fully comprehend the  details of the Budget.All I got is that to cut down the number of cars,the new COE policies have penalised low/middle income families and put us further from reach of car ownership.For some of us who really need a car because of the nature of our jobs or because we have both old folks and young children ,the new Coe policies have made it impossible to get a car,not even a lower  end one when our current expires.I didn't get anything of what you meant by 'quality' or 'inclusive' when now only the rich gets to own AT LEAST a car and the rest  of the average Singaporeans cannot afford one. I am not sure if my family is the  only one in this bitter predicament.Please sir.I beg  you.Please make some kind of concessions(allow longer loans/lower cash payment) for families who really need a car.
You, I meant the government talked about helping Singaporeans in pursuing part-time studies ... having more subsidy coverage ... Why this is not in the budget? Disappointed ...

Dear Edna and Scope Guy, there is indeed more to do to help displaced Singaporean PMETs, especially those who are mid or late in their careers. They deserve jobs that allow them to make good use of their experience, and that pay reasonably. Many have large financial obligations, and the difficulties for the family is often signficant. There is still some bias in the market against older PMETs from what I can see. WDA has stepped up its programmes for Singaporean PMET placements over the last year. MOM is also  tightening entry of Employment Pass holders (especially the mid-level), which is why the total number of EPs fell last year. Further, we signalled clearly in the Budget that MOM is studying a framework to ensure that employers give fair consideration to Singaporeans when they hire. But I must let you know too that the idea that each CDC officer or even all the officers at a CDC sees 100s of people a day looking for jobs is wildly off. I am in close touch with the CDC, and with the employment market. Regardless, we must try our best to help each individual. Can do better. Best rgds, TS

Dear sir, I need your help. My father in law's car was expired few days ago. He is more than 60 years old. He is unemployed and he has no income. We are giving allowances him every month. He is using the van to fetch my mother in law who is a handicap semi paralyses for therapy. Now he has no vehicle to fetch my mother in law for therapy. COE is too high for a 10 years old vehicle. We have to take leaves to fetch my mother in law for therapy. It is going to be hassles for us to take care of mum, work and children at the same time. Is there any scheme to help handicap candidate? We need a vehicle to ferry my mother in law around for therapy and treatment.
Dean, I understand the difficulty. Can you pl message me with your e-mail address. Families in this circumstance often look to the used car market. But let me see what can be done. Rgds, TS

Dear Sir, thank you for your concern. By the way, my family and my father in law are very strong supporter of PAP. You guys are doing good job for the whole Singapore. But I hope you can be less strict on curbing the foreign workers and car loan.
Dear Mer Lion,thanks for taking the effort to explain the new ruling in such great detail.Appreciate it.

I have supported 3 generations of my family members since I was 16 years old: My grandmother, my mother and myself.  My father was a government pensioner getting S$400, and my four older siblings gave little help. I managed to secure scholarships in good foreign universities abroad, and financed over 90% of my own education. Upon seeing the dire low fertility rate in Singapore, I felt a sense to get married even though I entered my fifties. Now I am supporting my wife also who is 16 years younger than me. I am therefore now looking at supporting the fourth generation in my family. The current economic situation is such that I may not be able to retire anytime soon or at all!
Clearly quite a bit of work to steer this ship back on course. We await with bated breath on the transformation of Singapore. Some of my thoughts

1. Not enough enducation of industry segments and job opportunity to the young. Bring complanies from simlar industries to sponsor job placement fairs. Give them the voice to Educational Institutes. Change their peception that they need to hire abroad to get the talent. Incentivise them to take the talents from our excellent eduction institutions and groom them instead.   2. 200k maids adds to the foreign worker burden. Make live in mads easy for families that need it like the ones that have very young children etc and make it difficult for the rest. 3. Be brave and remove the systems that don't work (should we move away from the GCE system and be heavier on the IB - we want our childern to be successful after they graduate and not juste celebrate their educational successes. Cheers LInus

Hope that in the next round of review on the car loan limits, we could at least make it easier for family with 3rd child to buy a 2nd hand small car (still within financial prudence, if nec, those more than 5 years old). A family of 5 (esp when the children are older) can find it difficult to hire a normal taxi due to the typical seating capacity limit of 4 passengers. This can be another pro-family measure. Ideally, the same suggestion can be applied to family with babies, if this relaxation does not compromise significantly the effectiveness of the car loan measures on COE prices.
Mr. Tharman, pls reconsider car loans restrictions for family with young children whose lives will be much more convenient with a car.
Mr. Tharman, I am not even talking about brand new car. Used Car loans should be less stringent for the families.

The MAS announced certain exemptions on the TDSR and MSR today.  This comes two days after Kwek Leng Beng- a billionaire who made his riches by selling homes - appealed for removal of the cooling measures.

Yes, COVs are coming down.  However, COV alone is not a real indication of home prices as valuations have increased at least some 30pc since 2009.
