Happy Ponggal Minister Sir

So the question is 2fold. How do u get restaurant owners to find ways to be more efficient and convince society that their demands for less foreigners means we have to change our mindset on what services in f&b means?

When we were in kyoto, at the cultural museum, there is a coffee shop, about close to 15 tables, 4 chairs each, lunch time full house - only one girl worked all by herself. Serving, taking order, cashier, washing n table cleaning. And she bowed to each one of us at the time we leave and enter the restaurant. My daughter was 7 at that time - she was amazed of how fast, graceful, productive and efficient of the waitress worked. And she was neat, happy and friendly - amazing!
It's the attitude that drives
Productivity board to bring in Japan, Germany,  Swiss F&B consultant s to work w us!  They've been there & done that!  Nothing new to them,  but v v new to us!  Just sharing!  Others industries too!
Sir, noticed sheng xiong started to employ students due to our shift in policy.

I have to agree! Cheaper does not necessary better. We need to review our workforce quality, i am pro to invest more for singaporean to do the job. I know based on my experience 5 heads job in other country can be done by 1 head here in shorter time.
Aiyah close lor and go Iskander Corridor lah.

Professor Brawn's Cafe in Velocity Mall employs people with intellectual disabilities. They receive training before they start working. Based on my visits there, they are working out very well. They know the menu and are prompt with their service. I have never had a bad experience, and the food is pretty good, too! How is that for a successful social enterprise?!

It is not the high pay or even age that is going to spur them on even further.. These companies, overseas, practice something totally different. You will find out that the successful ones have employees that are stakeholders of the restaurant or company or whatever. If the company does well, they will get a higher pay; if it does badly they would be affected as well.  THerefore, everyone truly has a part to play in the success of the business and will give their utmost in the running of it...

Indeed. I've been in restaurants in Singapore where I've seen four to five staff just standing or joking around. I've also had extraordinarily bad service in restaurants crawling with staff - food arrives in the wrong order, really late, or in really bad condition. More doesn't mean better. The question is how to get employers to invest in training staff, not just hiring them - my sense is, they'll train and treat staff better if they're not that easily replaced.

Minister Sir, I urge the government to persist in tightening the entry requirements for foreign labour, and have businesses that refuse to adapt suffer the consequences of 'creative destruction'.

The wider Singapore population has been absorbing the externality costs of this business dependence on foreign labour for many years, so it is time for them to realise that their profits cannot be indirectly subsidised by the rest of us indefinitely.

Its not just about employers or employees and whatnot. Its about our mindset. We like to think of waiting, retail jobs, etc as menial jobs unworthy of us. The lowest rung on the ladder, or a temporary burden while we search for a high paying job with advancement opportunities. Changing that mindset is going to take convincing our parents, our peers and ourselves that a career like Herr Gurnior's is as much a success as being a doctor, lawyer, banker or high level manager.

Absolutely spot on and I'm just in awe of your sharp observations of an issue that plagues all Singaporeans. Productivity is the key - not profitability at any cost as  most food places seem to be motivated by.

To give some credit to our local companies, I have seen a few restuarants adopting IT to improve their productivity. A particular J seafood restaurant now allows customer to place order from the tablet PC beneath the table, which saves precious manpower. I think this is the right way to go and probably room to do more, including changing some of the manpower-consuming practice like frequent / unnecessary changing of plates during dining.

Of course, fellow customers will also need to adjust their expectations and be more patient. These days, I just pick up the extra pair of fork and spoons myself than to wait for the waitress to come by.
The key is educated workforce n automation ... I m sure we can do it!

In the quest for good customer service, the problem lies in communication, language barriers. The service staff may be trained in one language but is expected to converse in many with their customers. Our foreign bus captains for example, are not always trained to handle customers questions about destinations. It's easier for European countries, NZ, Japan, Taiwan or Australia because there's homogeneity in language fortified by their strong cultures.

Minister Sir, agreed! I have been studying in Europe and am in Finland now with my host family. My dear Finnish friend works in bar and serve customers and they runs 2 bars with 3 workers. All in one! They knew every single job and multi-tasks. Customer service precise. Well- paid and absolute pride in doing the job. At the same time, customers know their individual expectation and do their part without prejudices. Paradigm must change in order to believe and see that Singaporeans have changed...

Sir i hope you are reading our comments, before i go to sleep few things to add: we need to start introducing the culture of working part time for our kids - many they can do barista at starbuck, CD shops , bookshop etc. then our education system sir! Are we preparing our kids by giving them the right curriculum on creativity on problem solving, analysis, task oriented etc especially on digital environment with interactive approach instead just expecting them memorizing facts. We have great infrastructure in school ... Just help upgrade our educator on their knowledge base. Okay! Good night sir ... It's school day tom. Cheers everyone, all the best for singapore

In Australia, foreign students are allowed to convert their visas to working visas. All they need to do is to submit an application together with a nominal fee. These students are allowed to work a maximum of 20 hours per week. Employers who breached this will be fined. That's why lots of these students work as waiters or waitress in restaurants.
Student working visa that is.

I think in Tokyo, services and processes are so streamlined that in many instances, not more than three staff are needed to run a fast-food restaurants servicing Jap food. Some restaurants do away with cashiers with a venting/ticketing system at the entrance before ordering. It works also because of good dinning habits. Workers need not clear tables as trays are returned to allocated spot and no mess to clean up after the customers. Japaneses are fastidious about cleanliness and it shows.
i actually read every comment, although i don't intervene often. this is a most thoughtful discussion. TS

Another could be the service charge here vs the tipping culture overseas maybe ? Those waiting tables have totally no motivation to provide good service since they are hardly rewarded for good performance in the first place .

In NZ and Australia, the service industry are support by a large number of workers on working holiday visa. As it is a relatively competitive industry, there is no lack of good services or language barriers because overseas applicants have to pass the English test in their home countries to qualify. Met a PRC girl working with such visa in NZ. She told me it took her 3 mths in Shanghai to pass the qualifying tests to secure the visa.

Yes, I fully agree that more staff doesn't necessarily mean efficiency. I have been to shopping centres here where staff gather to chit chat and I have to call out loudly to them to help me. Training and good management are very crucial. Also the mindset of people of different ages towards work has to change. I was served by an elderly lady in Melbourne once. I was looking for a microwave and was absolutely lost as there were lots of different models and brands. She came to help me. She asked me a few questions and went on explaining the functions and compared the different brands within my budget. Her knowledge and the pride she had in her job simply amazed me. I can't find this same standard in staff here. This boils down to the lack of management and training of staff here.

I also notice that in some parts of France, small towns in areas around Dinah for example, in small local bistro, the waiters are fully uniformed. At times you may notice that amongst the many certificates that adorned the interior walls of the restaurants, included are certificates for table serving. However, the services are only communicated in French.

I believe to improve productivity in the local food industry, we need to face those challenges that are uniquely Singaporeans. Overseas examples are motivating but they are not always relevant. Basically, our education is different and so is our cultures. How about another white paper to tackle the issue? Obviously faster, cheaper, better don't work...

My friend who works as a cabin crew told me her personal experience. At work, one customer actually pointed a finger at her and told a little girl seated next to her that if she(the little girl) didn't study hard, she would end up doing job like my friend. 
My friend took pride in her job and she was quite shocked of the comment. She wondered which part of her job was considered a disgrace.
If people don't change their mindset about service jobs, be it on ground or in air, the fundamental problems will never be changed.

Dear minister, human resource is only one of the multiple challenges faced by F&B operators in Singapore. Rentals of premises have escalated many folds in the last few years - landlords need to get enough returns to service their mortgages - and this may well be the main reason why outlets have to cut back on operation cost in order to keep the business viable. Naturally, a lower staff overhead is the first to be adjusted but that move comes with a heavy price. You throw peanuts, you get monkeys. Perhaps operators should come up with more creative remuneration packages that will allow the staff to have a share when it comes to profits. The chance of a better income (beside their monthly salary) is the surest motivation for anyone to want to upgrade their skills in order to be more productive because he/she has a stake in the business. Its all in the mind but it must come from the heart.
looks like we can work part time tis CNY

Could the reason of looking for foreigners to fill the jobs be the complacency of the F&B owners? For years, they solve the problem by taking the easiest way out by hiring more due to the convenient policy of getting staff from overseas. In comparison, looking internally at work procedures and management style is lots more difficult and sometimes more damaging to their egos as it could mean that they do certain things wrongly or inefficiently. Due to the government's style of making business operations here a breeze, business owners here have an easier time as compared to other countries. Therefore, business owners here are not as creative and resourceful as many other places.

i have to say, the population in EU or Japan isnt as dense as SGP... higher productivity = more stress in an already stressed environment!! yet, i suppose it doesn't matter if we "don't want" to become as stressful as these ppl are in other countries; tightening manpower policies = "the tide going out, see whose naked" concept... shape up or ship out... shock therapy; so stress @_@. then again, i'm not really sure if having our youth working as waiters/baristas is the best use of manpower for SGP, considering that there are some who say that SGP needs "high value added jobs" to stay relevant.

Happy new year Sir, hope all is well. I think good service comes from the heart, not solely from software (policies) nor hardware (setup). We have been to many places, yet Japan and Scandinavia springs to mind when we think about product quality and pride in one's profession. 
There are many reasons and factors for such a "phenomena" (going by SG standards), I.e Homogeneity, culture, pride, cost n standards of living. However, from my observations, clearly government policies are not the main driving factors. 
So what drives good service?
In my view, ownership and empowerment. Business Management theories, psychological studies and many philosophical thinking have shown that it takes more than just externalities in order for one to push oneself harder or further. 
What makes one go the extra mile? Carrot or stick? Or both?
When one looks to buy oneself a mobile phone, a dinner dress or a fancy dinner, one will likely take some time n spend some effort to at least consider a few factors before arriving at the "best" decision. 
If one can emulate that in our chosen line of service, be it as a business owner, manager, banker, teacher or waiter, the end result would be very different from that of someone who is simply "passing through the motion".

When you bring in economics theories of motivation which all very well serves a purpose in the big picture of macroeconomics, we neglect the human aspect, and the real motivation behind why everyone of us take up jobs. we shld stop being so shortsighted and look at price, time to look at value and ideational factors as well.

at the same time, I wonder why is no one questioning the increasing cost that is attributed to rising rents. aren't property developers/owners to blame for fueling inflation at the micro level as opposed to some bigger picture of exchange rate policy? are we that harped up for asset appreciation at a cost to other parties?

1) shift in resident mindset-our parents and grandparents had been "guided" to view academic achievers moving into "office" jobs as the upper class path. Anyone else, from teachers to service crew to technician to craftsmen, as poor achievers destined for a "hard" life.  Thus these down to earth jobs which need trade expertise (no less!) are viewed lowly. Society prejudice creates adverse uptake of such job/skills. Those who enter such trade tends to be low achievers who could not pick up the true skills of the trade. We thus have a self fulfilling outcome. Government can play a part to shift the mindset, work on the necc propaganda.

Uncle Tharman, We are all growing in families who are served, do not truly appreciate the meaning of service, nor wish to be part of being a servant... maybe thats why? My dad ask us to help our friend's stallholder parent (hawker) during school holidays and we have learn to understand and enjoy...  How great can we be when we grow up if we cannot understand the strife nor appreciate the hard work of others... What do you think, sir? What do you think we can do to help build the spirit and pride in service excellence...? By the way, I am very please when the people I help serve acknowledge the service and some even have me keep the change, though I always return them.  :)

2) shift in remuneration-salary compensation to reflect the true value of each trade's value of an artisan. We have depress wages for too long to give false impression of value of such non office jobs.

3) restrict foreign intake of employees - as someone said earlier, force operators to move out of comfort zone and not be sheltered by the social and financial cost it take in the whole country population. They take ownership to run the business within the social-eco of SG, not force the population to conform to their business model.

It is no longer an issue of manpower. It has become an issue of overcrowding due to over population. There are many industries where infrastructure and equipment are equally important for a business to run. Do we have enough space for this capacity? restaurants can have more staff but is there enough space for the staff to do work productively? What is the use of talking about productivity when everyone is frustrated because there is no longer enough affordable space? Even a well trained, well paid staff can get frustrated with the environment here. It does not take a genius to figure out the root cause of the many fold problems Singapore is facing now!

4) review property prices- runaway prices hurts business AND the people at large. The ones laughing to the bank are the big players in the property market and whoever involved with them. We are now not paying for tangible goods and service but more to fill up coffers of certain groups.

5) skill transfer through generations - reinstate the master-apprentice system back to our society. This system imparts skills and value set, and more importantly, teaches the apprentice to use his heart (something SG has lack for many years) Thus only those who have truly rooted themselves to the country and the society will find success in the apprenticeship. Each industry on its own need to put this back, this is not a one company only effort. Only then can we groom future generations of successors for each trade.

If government is truly concerned, start working with the relevant trade organisation, training school, companies, grassroots. We have many knowledgeable residents on this little island. If you truly use your heart to listen, you will hear much wisdom. A conversation will lead to positive outcomes only if taken without prejudice and baggage.

Dear DPM, 
I recall being served by elderly waiters in Europe too.  I now recall a drama in Vasantham. It was about the relationship between father and son. The relationship broke down. It was because the father worked as a cleaner in a coffee shop and the son was asked by friends why did he allow  his father to work in a coffee shop!?  Son was ashamed and disliked his father because his father did not stop working in the coffee shop even after he asked him to stop. The father continued to work there because he was respected and appreciated. 
When the son was strapped for cash, it was his cleaner father who rescued his business. Moral of the story was respect all occupations. Respect one's choice of employment. 
If customers have deep respect for those who wait to serve them to their satisfaction and customers show appreciation and generosity, we may see more  cafes and restaurants like in Europe. Productivity will be easily achieved. Thank you.

I have spoken to a few restaurant owners recently, and they shared that rising labour cost is indeed one of the problems they face. However the main issue is more of rent. They feel that the extremely high rental, which will only go up every year due to the heavy presence of REITS here, has caused it to be very unattractive to do business here. Therefore they will try to cut cost in every way possible, including hiring cheaper workers. 
Some also indicated difficulty in hiring Singaporeans, who seem to have poorer work attitude and tend not to stay in the job. They therefore prefer to hire foreigners who can be trained and are more like to stay in the job. 
I believe these problems are not only faced in the F & B industry, but in almost every other small company.

May I just add that restaurant/business owners have to deal with many public agencies as a matter of course: NEA, URA, MOM, ACRA, IRAS, CPF, AVA, HSA, WDA.  The most difficult part of my job as a business owner is dealing with them.  To name a few peeves:
a) what's with the long list of terms & conditions that we have to agree to when using their websites, that indemnify them from any responsibility whatsoever & place all the burden on the website users? 
b) why are MOM/WDA websites only accessible during selected hours of the day?  Is it to convenience civil servants, but at users' expense?  Don't they know we are busy running our businesses during the day, & might need to log in at night?
c) Recently I changed our business address, & informed ACRA accordingly.  I was shocked when NEA sent their licence renewal notice to the old address - as a result, we were late for our renewal.  This only goes to show that government agencies don't share information with each other, as appropriate.
My conclusion therefore is that public agencies also have to improve their own productivity, such as in handling applications by companies or requests by citizens.  The following remain to be seen: whether there is a co-ordinated effort across government agencies to improve collaboration, what progress has been made with the whole-of-government approach to national issues, and how fiscal prudence and discipline is ensured across government.

Besides wages, the cost of rental is killing businesses in Singapore. In overseas, rental cost is low because the gov has a part to play in keeping rental cost low. We need strategic and transformative leadership in our country to solve these problems, and not one that just fight fire.

As I ponder on the root cause of our productivity issues, perhaps it boils down to the education system that focuses on results and a culture where everyone wants to be a banker or doctor or some other executive job that pays well - the focus we have had on economic growth is not helping.  As my son completed 6 years of primary school in 2012, I can only conclude the formula being taught is to get students to keep repeatedly working on problem sums so that they master the exam and ace it.  There was very little emphasis on working smart, real learning, real delivery of any results other than exam scores.  This, I believe, has led to a culture where service is not important, but one where beating the rest and getting maximum money for minimum effort with little regard for real contribution to service or how we impact others has become the norm (Just look at driver behaviour).  To me, it is not about rentals, or manpower policies, but the root problem is the culture we have built over the last few decades.  This will take a generation to change, and it starts with the leaders.  Are we willing to sacrifice economic growth for whilst we rethink?  Or are we going to continue the tactical rather than strategic long-term approach?  What are we going to do with the fact that Singaporeans are an unhappy lot?  How are we going to instill purpose and meaning in life and work (the answer is not money)?

Rental! 
Look at why Changi Motor sports didn't take off...
How much more productive can workers be? We have 2 hands and 2 legs and we are humanly limited by space and time. Even if labour productivity increases by 200%, businesses can only save on labour costs for as long as their tendency agreement ends. After which, the landlord will review the profit of the business and increase rental prices accordingly. So increase productivity by 300% after that?

Maybe inventing robots to serve dishes may do the job.... But even if productivity increases by 1000%, rental will always be just a step behind.... Unless the Government puts a stop to this. 

After all, the Governments job is to Govern. To bring order, to hold in check, to control.

Glad  u see the importance of paying top wages  to waiting staff and providing perks and ensuring the well being of those employees.
The buisnessman behind the local eateries either paid peanuts and made their staff do split shifts and extra long hours.
Why would any locals want to do this for such low pay?
Pay good wages n provide sane working hours and the locals will flock to Tis sector.

The local eateries owner always make use of local talent to set up the restaurant after everything is doing fine they will just terminate their service saying that they are not making money or finding the fault of the manager just because scolding lower rank worker or making thing right for the company. That is y our local employees is being very choosy.

I totally agree with Mr Shanmugaratnam's observation on the competency of restaurant staffs in Europe. I have made the same observation in Europe's restaurant and in their construction industry. Unfortunately, the Singapore Government themselves placed much emphasis on the size of the companies, ie. no. of staffs,  during their evaluation of the award of Contracts. I wonder if they can walk the talk themselves by expecting less but more productive personnel.
Best direction to fallow

I agree we need to transform our jobs and in particular transform our people in terms of attitudes towards their jobs, doing better and service excellence. I have observed the difference between our workers and their counterparts overseas for years (in Korea, Thailand, Australia etc) and often wondered why there was such a difference. Having more workers does not cut it, having quality workers is what is important. I went to a fish and chips outlet a year ago and was quite disappointed with the service. I went to another of their outlets recently and was pleasantly surprised by the waiter and waitresses that served us, professional...dramatic change...they are doing something right. One of the problems we face is that many people view jobs like sales at retail outlets as low class, low pay, not respectable. Same with waiters and waitresses, same with those in the building industry and many other jobs. Over time this became a reality because of these views. Our society and also in part the government has created these views - unconsiously, and this needs to change. There is nothing wrong with doing a sales job at a retail outlet - do it professionally, there is nothing wrong with being awaiter - again but do it professionally, there is nothing wrong with being a brick layer - but do a first class job of it.

In fact, it is about us not only on changing ourselves, organisations also need to change their old thinkings. If mid-career entrants are encouraged, why cant the govt sectors and private sectors change their mindsets too! It is double slapping their faces!

DPM, how can a country meets the ever demanding singapore population and yet try to stay afloat with their businesses pose the greatest challenge for many restaurant operators and businessmen out there. Well, the gov talks about skills upgrading to meet w job challenges for the ever changing economy and the rising literacy levels has greatly reduced  the  pool of reliable Singaporeans available for such demanding job scopes. (if they are that good, why would anyone aspire to be a waiter in the first place!). Most important of all, technology can only offer businesses this far in their operations. Human resources still forms part of the core of this service orientated industry! I don't agree that seeing things at the most surface elsewhere  would mean it could be applicable locally. The real difficulty is not about hiring sgaporeans but hiring reliable ppl to do the work. As businessmen, do u think we want to go thru the trouble of hiring FTs if we can get ppl locally. Pls ponder...
I come back to what I think could be wrong and can be improved. There are many issues and each has to be tackled, Icover only a few of the issues:

Sorry let me continue. Firstly we hire wrong people for the job and they dont get the right tools. I once walked past some workers painting the yellow line on the side of the road. There were 3 of them. One was holding a string so the other could paint a striaght line, the second man was doing the painting and the third a supervisor had his hands folded just watching. Obviously you are not going get a lot of productivity out of that. They did not have the tools ad often the foriegn workers we hire dont even have the language skills nor job skills so obviously once again we will not get a lot of productivity out of them and the language skills dont allow for easy upgrading. By the time we train them up they go some place else, I dont mean another company I mean another country. Take maids for instance. Many come with little or no experience, after 2 years they leave and go elsewhere where they get more pay, so we bear the cost of training. We then take on the next maid and the cyle continues. Continuing on the issue of language I was in a counry once and the immigration officer a lady could hardly speak english. She asked me 'Where is my visa?' But what she said was more like 'WHat is your visa'. I was a little confused so she asked again. By the time she asked the thrid time she was raising her voice, so I said you mean 'Where is my visa?', I then quickly added 'No visa'. We don't need a visa to enter her country, as an immigation officer surely she should know that. Language is an issue affecting delivery of services. Then there is my observation of a mee pok stall that I observed. There were 3 persons. One was cooking, another collecting the money and the third person getting the spoons and chopsticks for the customers. No doubt the one doing the cooking was very busy and the other 2 didnot have much to do, here we have a deployment problem - not effective. There are other issues but no need for me to go on I think. There are many issues and each has to be resolved one by one some by government policy, some by individual employees, some by management of companies, some through training, job scope redesign, emphasis on pay for skills and teamwork etc etc. A multi-prong approach is needed

the one thing he didn't mention is that a lot of restaurants in the US treat their staff like family or at least treat them well with welfare in mind.  hence, they are proud of what they do, because they were at least treated as humans being.  and how do i know that?  i used to live there.

plus, in general, employers can't discriminate on sex and age.  though we know that the US employers have bottom line in their minds but most don't use that as a means to hire and fire, in fact, they prefer to retain and give fair wages.  unlike here, you need to be young and perky.  our DPM seems to be very selective in this piece.

I've been in this business for the past 21 years, all I keep hearing is... The foreigners are taking up our jobs. There's no jobs for the locals. That is entirely not true. There are so many vacancies in the service sector but no Singaporeans are walking in to fill up the forms. Leaving us minority Singaporeans struggling in these industries working long hours due to manpower shortage. The new age part timers are students whom rather not work over the weekends and choosing only to work from Monday to Thursday, 9-5.

Isn't this easier said than done? Without any offense, this is rather obnoxious. Why don't you serve a week in a restaurant with less staff, who are apparently well paid with more duties that brings in $12,000 a day and tell me if this is feasible. Firstly, many F&B outlets do not pay competitively. Secondly, less staff can mean longer waiting times at peak periods too. This leads to the question of just how tolerant Singaporean patrons can be? Less staff also means less hands to go around and shoulder the team's daily duties. They are seriously stretched thin! I am a fortunate 9am to 6pm paper pusher seated behind a comfy desk. Every time I dine in restaurants, my heart goes out to service staff scrambling to serve our every need. When we sit for down for a long lunch or a great dinner with friends, does it occur to us that these service staff don't get these luxurious lunch or dinner breaks? They are on their feet the whole day with only a half an hour to 45min break to get a bite to eat. Can you imagine eating at only 4pm when you've been at work since 9am? Less staff means less hands to go around when break time rolls around. In the end? Many staff don't eat or they cram food behind the counter in 5 mins and poof they're back to serving tables. I cringe every time I see a more than demanding customer gesture rudely at service staff- eh Hello! Where did basic courtesy go to?  They wear name badges for a reason. It's not just there for you to take their names downs to complain. Like you and I, they have feelings. As I grow older in this country I love and will always call home; I find myself greatly sadden and disturbed by the way we have become. Were we really brought up to be that intolerant and obnoxious? I long to be proud to say I am Singaporean when I stand in my expatriate filled office. But instead when I hear them trash Singaporeans, I stand there blushing because what they say is true. So DPM, please consider both sides of the coin before posting such things. This goes beyond stirring a lively debate. This involves real people with real struggles. Having a stimulating discussion on this matter will not ease their work situations. Neither will it miraculously teach Singaporeans compassion.
Kudos Sharmaine Rose Selvakumar

Wonder if Sharmaine has read the post clearly enough. Tharman is talking about real situations and sharing how restuarants in other countries like US, Europe and Japan, and even Hong Kong are managing with less staff through better training, assignment of duties, (and use of IT).  The resulting productivity has allowed the staff to be better paid, and plus their own pride in their work and the respect accorded by their customers. I have seen such restuarants myself while abroad, and I have observed some of our local restuarants like the J seafood restuarant are also moving in this direction. Surely this is the kind of situation or outcome that I think Sharmaine would also like to see, judging from her comment. Not sure why she appears to disagree with Tharman.

Precisely, the current situations in our restuarants are not tenable in the long run and that's why we need to advocate productivity improvement, matched by better pay and training, leading to staff with pride and service quality. And on the other hand, of course, we as customers will also need to be understanding and accord the service staff with due respect and cooperation.
Plus the restuarant owners / bosses must of course play their part !

Multi-tasking should be a good part of our training in productivity.  Yes our restaurants have more workers than those in most European countries. I have entered into restaurants here where waiters and waitresses cannot speak or understand customers' English. Even domestic maids are better in productivity because they have to pass basic English to work and have to handle multiple tasks at homes How than can we be productive. I had also written to SGConvariation that 10 per cent service charge, on top of GST,  is a factor of high inflation that is deterring our  economic growth

Dear Minister, there were many previous attempts and initiatives by the government to help businesses improved their productivity. Eventually, they don't work and we have to fall back on cheap foreign labour. I think it's time for the government to be 'hands off' in such initiatives.The private sector has to feel the urgency and pressure to innovate for productivity gains. They have to take ownership of their business. No doubt, some will not survive. That is part of the transformation in an industry. What the government can do, maybe, is to have policies that help to stabilise /reduce rental cost, which made up a large part of the cost of running a business.

Dear DPM TS, please find in the link http://eprints.qut.edu.au/view/person/Lee,_Boon.html some papers I have written on Singapore's efficiency and productivity which have been published in academic journals. Hopefully, the information should provide some useful ideas for future policies. :)

I just wonder why in this labour intensive society, we still see some older people out of job. Should look into this problem seriously. If older people stay out of job for too long due to retirement they will soon get sick.

Sir you are absolutely spot on...but what may have been missed out is that in many restaurant / f&b businesses, the biggest overheads apart from COGS is often the rent. Asset prices are bubbling like never before and business owners have difficulty meeting rent payments. F&B workers should be paid well so they m&a take pride in their jobs and perform the service well. Service charge of 10% should go to the employees or the tip box, and not the business owner. Given the already entrenched mind sets of us Singaporeans, I don't see a tipping culture becoming a possibility in the near future. That being said, much has to be done to improve the livelihood of waiters and the possibility of making a livelihood out of being a service staff, such that more Singaporeans may find it viable and take up such jobs. Wage levels need to be improved upon, and possibly a minimum wage should be implemented as a future policy. Thanks
tipping is not our way of life here,...whereas the US  F& B  {restaurant} servers accept tips......standard i think difference...

PM Lee said that he would like the White Paper on population to be further discussed widely by Singaporeans.  He welcomes Singaporeans to bring more suggestions to the Govt for consideration in planning forward.
We can expect many Singaporeans to voice their ideas in the coming months.  
This morning 16th Feb 2013 ST's Life has an article "The rocky road to future growth", and Workers' Party's letter in ST Forum: "WP's position on foreign workers has been consistent".
We can only expect the 'public mass protest' this afternoon at Hong Lim Park's Speakers' Corner will be boisterous in rejecting the White Paper in total.   However, I hope the speakers and aspiring politicians will put forth sound and solid suggestions as well.
In the months to come, there will be many suggestions but will the Govt really listen to the good ideas and take it into consideration and deliberate on it decisively?
2013 to 2030 ‚Äì 17 years
We can expect many senior politicians in Singapore will retire or pass on within these 17 years.
It will be the same in Indonesia and Malaysia.
Will the younger politicians of these 3 countries build up close rapport with confidence and trust among themselves free of past political emotional baggage to plan ahead?
What should they do in the coming years looking forward at what they want to achieve when they are in charge?
They might not agree on all things geo-politics but surely they can take steps to plan ahead in areas of economics and development to counter the threats for investments and jobs that could go to big states like China and India.
From economics and development there would be less hungry people.  There will be a better chance for their countries to be politically stable and free of turmoil and mass uprising. 
What are the threats economically and what should be done within these 17 years? 
Iskandar Shah in Johor and the Bataam and Bintan Islands in Indonesia are potentials to counter the threats for jobs and investments flowing towards China and India.
Will there be plans to make these places into future economic hubs thriving with activities and growth?
To achieve this will need lots of investments, capital and good infrastructures to make the connections for easy access to Singapore.
Where can Singapore fit in and what is in it that will make it win-win for all 3 countries?
Singapore has projected to grow its population to 6.9m by 2030.
Rather than allow in foreigners from far away countries, people who are not familiar with our culture in South-East Asia, it would be better for Singapore to look at Malaysia and Indonesia as the traditional sources to fill the gap in our labour force. 
To house a bigger population will mean building 700,000 residential units.   If we take an average of $100,000 in construction cost, it would mean investing $70bn in 17 years in housing.   
Housing a bigger population by investing $70bn.  Are there other alternatives?
We can look North or South for the alternatives.
If the foreign workers coming from Malaysia and Indonesia could reside there, and commute to Singapore to work, it would free the massive congestion that could be expected when the population reaches 6.5m or more in Singapore.
I hope the younger politicians of these 3 countries will work together to plan ahead on this for mutual benefits.
A] There is a need of a MRT rail line to connect Singapore to Johor.  If we cannot reclaim land on both sides of the Causeway to widen it, I hope land could be reclaimed to build the MRT line [tunnels under the Johor Straits will be expensive] with provisions for a future Rapid Rail to connect Singapore to Iskandar Shah and Kuala Lumpur.   The MRT line to Johor will mean developments in many economic activities other than housing in Southern Johor.   It will free Singapore from massive congestion with a huge population.   Instead of pumping $70b in 700,000 units of housing, I hope the Singapore Govt will work with the Malaysian/Johor Govt on this project with a timeline of 10 to 17 years to see it materialize.
B] If the younger politicians of Indonesia could work with their Singapore counterparts, there could be  a plan among them to build a tunnel/expressway/MRT rail connection from Singapore to Batam/Bintan.   This idea was mooted some 20 years ago but has not been forgotten by both sides as it has been kept in abeyance.   It would mean opportunities in many social activities not just economics when the physical connections are built.   Some of the $70bn could be deployed to build these physical infrastructures for workers from Indonesia to have residence in these 2 islands but find employment in Singapore.  It would free Singapore from massive people congestion when the population grows to above 6.5m by 2030.
C] If the physical connections in A and B are built, it would mean retirees might find it easier to commute and stay in Johor or these 2 Indonesian islands.   It would relieve congestion of people in Singapore and bring more economic activities to Johor, Batam and Bintan.

Kok Tim, thanks for these thoughts. We have no intention of getting anywhere close to 6.9m by 2030. But we should work with our immediate neighbours to open up oppportunities -  under any population scenario will bring benefits for us and them.  TS

Tks Minister Tharman for the comments.  Very much appreciated. I agree no intention to reach 6.9m as it is only a planning target.  Even if it is below 6m, I hope we can open up the contacts with north and south to relieve the pressure on our land , tight and limited infrastructures to bring them spin-off benefits too.  Let us be prepared to give them a bit more and not always that we must be the winner in every deal.  I hope all can see the bigger picture and not miss the wood for the trees.  I hope the younger politicians of both sides without the political emotional baggage of the past can get together and work it out within the coming 17 years to bring about economic benefits and meet the challenges and competition from bigger countries like China and India.  I wrote on "A bridge to Bintan"  in the ST Forum sometime back. It is in my tankoktim at blog.com under Population category.

Marc, the way it is pronounced amongst the Tamils and those who speak the southern languages is DeePAAvali. When written in Tamil, it is unambiguous  -  the AA is extended. Since you asked about this, the "D" is also pronounced as "Th" in the south. Hence Theepaavali. Amongst the Hindi/Punjabi/Gujerati speaking groups and others from the north, it is the shorter Diwali.

Sir, to improve the current madness of paper chase in primary/secondary schools, allow only pass/fail as a score, do not even allow grading. Give the kids time to play and learn teamwork, values, etc. The government need to remove Primary/secondary schools from the application forms for jobs/scholarships.

besides ranking, the curriculum needs a re-look too, primary school education should focus on basic numeracy, literacy, writing and oral skills together with background knowledge of science, history, geography and general knowledge ... we do not need to introduce advanced material into primary school study ... there is a tendency in the education student to go outside the syllabus, for primary school students to look at subject matter for secondary school, and for secondary school to look towards tertiary level subject etc ... there seem to be a mad rush towards some unknown finishing line but really, in the haste to `learn', very often, we forgot to appreciate and really comprehend

in other words, back to basics ... we always forget the basics after all the numerous changes introduced over the years
finally somebody in the cabinet with an understanding of the problem. Too bad, one man isn't enough to convince the rest. Kudos nonetheless, Minister.

intelligences?

I would like to point out that examinations and the third point - "the ability to think for themselves and think in original ways" are not mutually exclusive.

I would suggest that  the 4 core subjects in primary school to  remain but the other subjects like art, music to be taken out as not all students have the aptitude for arts and music.  Students should be taught time management , having a balance of play and studies.  Apparently, most children spend more time playing than in studies. Also MOE should ensure that teachers be well equipped with the knowledge of teaching the primary school  part-whole models . I am speaking from my experiences as an ex primary school teacher.

I believe that while the notion stands that we should make changes and adopt a holistic education type of model, one of the key things that should be addressed will be the attitudes of teachers. Perhaps more flexibility can be given to curriculum and more freedom can be given to our educators to teach material that may not necessarily be examinable. 

i suppose that if teachers were only meant to be there to educate our young to excel in examinations, then we might just be nurturing a generation that is taught step by step on how to think and not given the opportunity to figure out things on their own which then defeats the purpose of education in general.

no offense to the teachers though. education has never been an easy job. kudos to you all.

Isn't the root cause the tight link between school placement and later economic returns in life ? So long as getting into the "right" school determines a child's future position in life, Pri 1 admission and PSLE will both be high-stakes and therefore stressful. It's not just alternative pathways in school, it's alternative pathways after. Note that I say "school placement" not "academic achievement". Meritocrats like to conflate the two, but they are not exactly the same.

Many people I know do not think that the education here is truly holistic - 3Rs still rule ... why? Social efficiency for economic purpose? But in total direct conflict with 21st century competencies ... Pedagogy approaches which are recommended should help us catch up for KBE but mindset of many school leaders and teachers have not (many not using those approaches for a more holistic education) - but can we blame them -  they have to manage the KPIs - PSLE results being the most obvious and tangible one.

Dear DPM, thank you for sharing your thoughts. It sounds that we are looking at incremental "enhancements" of the system rather than looking at a fundamental review of PSLE.  In my view, so long as we retain the high stake examinations (which has longer-term impact on the child's future) at such an early stage, nothing much will change.  

PSLE comes at a huge cost of learning.  The entire system - schools, principals, teachers, students, and admittedly, parents - is obsessed about getting exceptional PSLE scores.  That PSLE score would differentiate students, teachers, parents, principals and schools. 

I wonder if we are thinking hard enough for alternative framework.  Finland's more egalitarian approach on education (9 years of basic education without PSLE, streaming, Gifted programs) is one which we should look closely).  Finland's system is highly considered globally.  

You mentioned the need to retain our system in order not to erode confidence in Meritocracy.  At the same time, you mentioned that we should have more diversity in our top schools, but did not mention details.  Can you share your thoughts with us?  The need for diversity is important - in light of the ill effects of Meritocracy in making it harder for the have-nots to compete with the haves in society.

I agree with you that we should refocus to make sure that our children enjoy their childhood.  And enjoy learning.  

But that will not happen unless we have the courage to make fundamental changes.

To add on, the problem is not the granularity of the scores. It makes little difference to stress levels (and anti-learning impact) if you were to implement a system similar to the GCE  grading system. 

The core issue to me, is having a high stakes exam at a tender age of 12, and the consequential debilitating effects

For those if us less familiar with Finnish system:

The transformation of the Finns' education system began some 40 years ago as the key propellent of the country's economic recovery plan. Educators had little idea it was so successful until 2000, when the first results from the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA), a standardized test given to 15-year-olds in more than 40 global venues, revealed Finnish youth to be the best young readers in the world. Three years later, they led in math. By 2006, Finland was first out of 57 countries (and a few cities) in science. In the 2009 PISAscores released last year, the nation came in second in science, third in reading and sixth in math among nearly half a million students worldwide

It's admirable that Mr Tharman is able to understand the need for a "real space" so that our youths are able to learn how to think "originally" and critically about issues, and devise innovative solutions.

The government, however, needs to understand that it would be highly counterproductive if we were to create a space within the education system, yet not do so within broad society ‚Äì if in the general space, there are laws in place which prevent the ability to express freely and where certain issues are categorised as taboo, there is already structural impediments to what can be discussed ‚Äì there's self-regulation.

From a larger picture perspective, you want your youths to continue with the ability to have original and critical thinking abilities even after they leave the school system, and transit into the work system. In fact, it is of more value that they retain and expand on these abilities, especially in a knowledge economy, where such thinking abilities have a much more dire impact on the economy.

I urge the government to be bold. We cannot tell our youths to think openly and critically when there are rules in place outside of the school system which acts as countermeasures towards their thinking abilities. If there are still rules which prevent discussion against certain issues, such as race, religion and sexuality, how can we advance our critical thinking abilities in these areas, or other areas?

Of course, there are reasons for the government to want to impede on this a less controlled thinking environment ‚Äì the less critically people are able to think, the more they have a 'herd mentality' where they would follow whatever is said blindly, and the easier people are to control. Well, the government has to make a decision at this point ‚Äì how much do they want to continue to control and how much do they want to develop useful knowledge-based workers for the knowledge economy?

The government will undoubtedly still have OB markers in place, even if they create spaces within schools for "original" thinking. But the question is ‚Äì are rules the best way to manage people's thinking? Currently, the rules create a mentality of self-censorship. Is this what we want in the longer term? Self-censorship necessarily compromises on "original" and critical thinking abilities. We shut the thoughts out even before we can develop it further ‚Äì this will stunt our thinking abilities.

A stronger approach towards creating open and critical thinking abilities would be to educate and inculcate in people responsible thinking and speech, so that we will continue to be expansive in our thinking, yet be aware of how what we think or say will have an impact on others and then how we would put out what we say in a way that's honest, yet respectful and thoughtful towards others.

You put rules in place to prevent people from thinking and you create a society where there's underlying racism and discrimination, which we don't talk about because we've been told not to. You teach people to be responsible in their thinking abilities and you get them to think critically about these issues, such that it will move society towards a more aware and empathetic level.

There is a tight intertwining between our economic and social policies which are economically-inspired, and how these policies have a real impact on people's social behaviours, or lack thereof. If the government is sincere and truly empathetic on the need for Singaporeans to become more original and critical in their thinking, and more compassionate and kind towards one another, the government needs to understand how the broad structures that they have put in place over the years which allow for them to control effectively and to grow the economy can become counter-intuitive towards achieving a strong social fabric that ties society together.

At this juncture, the government needs to decide ‚Äì how much of control do they want to enact on people, and weigh it against how willing they are to let go of the control, towards enhancing the social and emotional well-being of the people? I would suggest that the government can relook their roles to be as facilitators to help create a thinking population which can think for themselves, and where the government aids in their thinking process. The government has shown signs that it's willing and wants to move in this direction. The question is also this ‚Äì the government cannot just think that they want to do things differently, but that they need to take down the structures which goes against their new thinking.

http://thehearttruths.com/2012/11/07/creating-a-thinking-society-singapore-government-needs-to-rebalance-control/

While we can appreciate the merits of NTUC taking swift action in an attempt to bring closure to this publicly contentious matter, one cannot help but wonder if the actions taken are in line with contemporary and accepted HR practices when it comes to handling matters of staff discipline, whereby warnings are issued for first time infractions and an outright termination, being a drastic decision, to be meted out to recalcitrant offenders.

Although the individual has to face up to the consequences of their actions, I wonder if the message put out by this move from the leading trade union in Singapore can have any long-term unintended consequences.

Notwithstanding any arguments on the basis of whether the punishment befits the offence proportionately, are we also putting out the message that an individual's right to gainful employment and a safe workplace environment is to be rendered subservient to the court of public opinion? If we allow such a mechanism to have a bearing on our general employment practices, then what of positions and offices that are by their very nature subjected to the forces of public opinion, such as political leadership and public servanthood? Where do we begin to draw the line, and how can we ensure that there are no double standards? Can we still continue to tout ourselves as a meritocracy when we hire or retain staffing based on their public popularity and not their capabilities?

Wielding the big stick so readily and heavily is also likely to send the message that "one should keep one's racist views to oneself" and drive other instances of such sentiments further underground, beyond the gauge of most known social barometers. The downside of this is that conversation and thought will then be stifled, while the brewing sentiments will continue to ferment, only to rear their heads in an unpredictable manner upon attaining critical mass. Do we really want this as a society heading into an increasingly uncertain future?

Have we as a society, amid the cheers and howls of applause at a fellow human being and a Singaporean who had just forfeited her means of livelihood over a momentary lapse of judgement, lost sight of an opportunity for a learning point to be had, that the same lapses can happen even to the best of us on a bad day? 

Some day, we all will have to recognise that fallibility is an integral part of the human condition, and that because of this fallibility we are all bound to have our own episodes of stupidity, with some episodes being more public than others. Unfortunately, going by how some quarters are weighing in on the issue and baying for blood as though they are paragons of virtue incarnate and incapable of the same human failings themselves, the arrival of that day is still but a distant hope.

1. We can NEVER do without foreigners. Well, almost. Will Singaporean do the dirty job that they're doing? How many in current generation would be willing to work as cleaners / construction workers? Joshua and Azhar both made a point which many overlooked. Our education system has taught us to strive for white collar positions which offers either comfortable scope of work or substantial amount of salary because workers are normally not paid well. Even if they're not well-educated, only a minimum would go be construction workers. 

2. Foreign workers do not exactly earn less. Especially PRC workers in construction sites. You'll be shocked to see the payslip of skilled PRC workers. If Singaporean is willing to learn, they can still earn well and help minimise foreign workers issue. If our government can also consider giving subsidies to companies who employe Singaporeans as skilled workers, the cost of housing shouldn't be much of an issue. 

3. Productivity can only be achieved if a certain baseline is set (eg. minimum tender price, grading of project productivity (including subcontractor's manpower deployment), technologies / methods to improve site productivity etc). It's difficult to invest in technologies when tender prices are declining. BCA is giving subsidies, but how many employers are willing to fork out substantial amount of capital when they can rely on manual labour where they reap instant rewards? 

4. Instead of using levies and man-years to control number of foreign workers, why not restructure the allocation? Industries like construction and cleaning definitely need more foreign workers so they should be given more man-years and charged with lesser levies whereby lesser man-years and higher levies should be given to other industries until there's an increase of Singaporeans working in the former industries.

5. To limit the amount of "foreign" Singapore citizens and Singapore PR, we can impose more stringent conditions such as studying in Singapore for >10yrs and serving NS like what most Singaporeans are 'tasked' to fulfil before considering foreigners to convert into Singapore citizens or PR.

Things cannot be changed in the short future but if we explore the above suggestions, we may find a solution to our problems in years to come (cross fingers it's sooner than later).

@brian Lee. Very good piece by you. Hope Tharman is listenting to this one and forward to the BCA for action.

Raising productivity is the key. Raising wage is not.

If we want to help low wage workers (LWW), can we just raise the wage of the workers in the Construction Industry alone? The answer is no. So to be fair, we will also have to raise the wage of cleaners, production operators, bus drivers, security officers, etc etc. The businesses which use the services of these LWW will then pass the cost on to the consumers. Inflation will then follow. Some may suggest the government subsidize these wage increase. Where then can the government get the money to do so? One way is from our reserves. Do we want that? No. Thus, the other way is from the taxpayers. Then Singaporeans will pay higher taxes. Businesses will pay higher taxes. Then Singapore will no longer be competitive. What will happen to Singapore next?

However, if the workers' productivity is increased, it is a different matter. There will be no increase in cost to the consumers because businesses will be able to accomplish the same job with less workers.

Do we want to encourage Singaporeans to go into the Construction Industry? Yes, but only certain areas. Only in the areas where the skill can carry the worker till retirement age. Construction is a tough job. Very manual and physical. When construction workers get to the age of 40+, they may not be able to take the toughness and physical demands anymore. Hence, We will then be left with a group of workers who are skilled but cannot get a job because of fitness reasons. Re-deploy these workers will be a problem. So, it is not wise to encourage the young to be construction workers even if the pay is $5000/month - unless they can move up the management ladder.

To my mind, these tough jobs should be left to the young foreign workers who can always be replaced when they get too old for the jobs. 

We need foreigners to help build our HDB flats, work in our shipyards, and do our city cleaning. There is no running away.

(Yes, I understand in developed countries, many of these jobs are paid well. But it doesn't mean that we have to follow whatever they do. Some of these countries provide for unemployment benefits. Do we want to follow them? If yes, will we be encouraging people to get unemployed?)

2013 to 2030 ‚Äì 17 years
We can expect many senior politicians in Singapore will retire or pass on within these 17 years.
It will be the same in Indonesia and Malaysia.
Will the younger politicians of these 3 countries build up close rapport with confidence and trust among themselves free of past political emotional baggage to plan ahead?
What should they do in the coming years looking forward at what do they want to achieve when they are in charge?
They might not agree on all things geo-politics but surely they can take steps to plan ahead in areas of economics and development to counter the threats for investments and jobs that could go to big countries like China and India.
From economics and development there would be more to share and less hungry people. There will be a better chance for their countries to be politically stable and free of turmoil and mass uprising.
What are the threats economically and what should be done within these 17 years?
Iskandar Shah in Johor and the Bataam and Bintan Islands in Indonesia are potentials to counter the threats for jobs and investments flowing towards China and India.
Will there be plans to make these places into future economic hubs thriving with activities and growth?
To achieve this will need lots of investments, capital and good infrastructures to make the connections for easy access to Singapore.
Where can Singapore fit in and what is in it that will make it win-win for all 3 countries?
Singapore has projected to grow its population to 6.9m by 2030.
Rather than allow in foreigners from far away countries, people who are not familiar with our culture in South-East Asia, it would be better for Singapore to look at Malaysia and Indonesia as the traditional sources to fill the gap in our labour force.
To house a bigger population will mean building 700,000 residential units. If we take an average of $100,000 in construction cost, it would mean investing $70bn in 17 years in housing.
Housing a bigger population by investing $70bn. Are there other alternatives?
We can look North or South for the alternatives.
If the foreign workers coming from Malaysia and Indonesia could reside there, and commute to Singapore to work, it would free the massive congestion that could be expected when the population reaches 6.5m or more in Singapore.
I hope the younger politicians of these 3 countries will work together to plan ahead on this for mutual benefits.
A] There is a need of a MRT rail line to connect Singapore to Johor. If we cannot reclaim land on both sides of the Causeway to widen it, I hope land could be reclaimed to build the MRT line [tunnels under the Johor Straits will be expensive] with provisions for a future Rapid Rail to connect Singapore to Iskandar Shah and Kuala Lumpur. The MRT line to Johor will mean developments in many economic activities other than housing in Southern Johor. It will free Singapore from massive congestion with a huge population. Instead of pumping $70b in 700,000 units of housing, I hope the Singapore Govt will work with the Malaysian/Johor Govt on this project with a timeline of 10 to 17 years to see it materialize.
B] If the younger politicians of Indonesia could work with their Singapore counterparts, there could be a plan among them to build a tunnel/expressway/MRT rail connection from Singapore to Batam/Bintan. This idea was mooted some 20 years ago but has not been forgotten by both sides as it has been kept in abeyance. It would mean opportunities in many social activities not just economics when the physical connections are built. Some of the $70bn could be deployed to build these physical infrastructures for workers from Indonesia to have residence in these 2 islands but find employment in Singapore. It would free Singapore from massive people congestion when the population grows to above 6.5m by 2030.
C] If the physical connections in A and B are built, it would mean retirees might find it easier to commute and stay in Johor or these 2 Indonesian islands. It would relieve congestion of people in Singapore and bring more economic activities to Johor, Batam and Bintan.
Caring for the elderly is very important, I hope other learnt from Sir.

My study life was never steady... It was full of hiccups and by the time in uni 3rd yr last yr, I'd to give up taking the exams because I realised it's really to the extent that I wonder just what did I really learn in NTU... By now, it's not that I never tried, but it's that the pace was too fast and I was not properly prep up for the expectation... Neither was it that I didn't sound off the alarm, regrettably no one understood my problems until I really didn't take the exam which I'd alrdy signalled to the admin staff the very intention to do so at the going rate...

I guess they must have thought no one would dare to take the risk of getting a F reflected on the transcript... But am I going to take into such threats for which I may go into mental breakdown for taking the paper and looking at the qn? Is it worth it? Though I must say it was avoidable had people took action earlier... 

I guess for that semester, I may be well known... for being the student that didn't even attend the exam without any MC or whatever in so many years... Least it's known that I mean it for what I say to the NTU admin staff... 

In fact I'd noticed this... It's my personal pov though... a lot of the standards were artifically inflated, I'm referring to how the lectures was conducted [lecturers that didn't really teach, expecting you to self study entirely] and how the exam paper are set...

This should be the real problem... No one is teaching anything, no one is willing to manage things...

Well said! But our education system, though it has improved a lot from what it was during my time, still pays staunch emphasis on academic achievement. Parents scramble to get their kids up on the academic ladder topped with a pile of other kinds of stress to be an all rounder, when the child doesnt want it. In many ways, the environment also creates this kind of pressure from the parents as competition is steep. Afterall, the idea that being a scholar guarantees one's ultimate success. In my opinion, the person creates the journey. You observe the environment and modify your methods along the way. How good and vibrant the outcome will be determined by one's intelligence, perseverence and creativity. The type that knows no boundaries to succeed and the type who shows sheer guts to knock down people or walls that come in front of them. However, there are crazy times when things don't work out somewhat. The reset and restart can be tedious. And no matter how tough the person is, it is time spent and gone. It cannot be taken back. Whilst some obstacles are understandable and self inflicted, some may be man made and should not be there in the first place. For some individuals, talent and gift may not come that soon. But they may have suffered from academic failure or lackluster grades at some point when they were young. But that doesn't imply they are unintelligent. But our system still appears to pin the past more than what these people have gone through and achieved. Personally, I have learnt far more from these so called non-elites than I learnt from anyone in the top tier of the academic cirlcle.  Because their life paths are less smooth, they pick up way more knowledge than those who think they know it all. Complacency and ego can degarde even the brightest. In many ways, the best leaders may not come from those smooth sailing academic high fliers. It is those who have fought it through, and learn humbly from all people of all walks of life that makes a leader. I sure hope that our system does not deprive people, whatever their age, creed or background from a chance to shine. There is simply only one life to live. No one likes to get blundered. For some laziness and unmotivated thoughts are the cause for failure. But for a good number, I think they deserve a chance.

@Tony, u sure LHL makes a speech openly supporting foreigners? What did he say exactly?

@Tony, what LHL wrote on his page appears to be more reflective of what he actually said: 

www.facebook.com/leehsienloong   

"On relations between Singaporeans and non-Singaporeans, PM said it was fair for people to express concern or to disagree with immigration trends and policies, but he was worried by some of the nasty views expressed, especially online and anonymously. This, he said, speaks poorly of who we are and damages our international reputation. 

He urged Singaporeans to show a generosity of spirit to one another, including toward new arrivals. He urged new arrivals to also make the effort to embrace our values, commit themselves to Singapore and integrate into our community."

I recall LHL was also talking about not being one-eye dragon i.e. there is need to also highlight and praise good behaviour or acts of foreigners so that we can encourage such, and not just choose to see or emphasize the bad behaviour or acts. This way we will be perceived as fair by fellow Sg, and rest of world.

"We must remain people who show understanding and empathy to our fellow citizens".  Very good Mr Tan. Please start by showing "understanding and empathy" to those who collect cardboard boxes and tin cans so they can eat and pay rent, those who can't afford medical treatment, those who can't afford to provide for their family in spite of a job or when they don't have a job, those who struggle to look after their family because they have to work
long hours because their employers threaten to replace them with cheaper foreign labour if they don't. The list goes on. You get my drift.

1) We're not xenophobic
2) We're not anti-foreigners as long as they add necessary value
3) We're not anti-immigration

What we want is a fair opportunity to lead a life as a Singaporean in Singapore & be proud of what we've achieved. What we want is a safe & secure environment to raise a family & kids. We understand that the competition is global these days, but we will differentiate & compete effectively to create economic value. We want space & balance in life...and not everything is a statistic digit.

Give us room to grow, explore, experiment. Don't crowd us out. Let those who deserve come in, and don't do immigration indiscriminately. We're angry because the influx was very quick & with little warning. Treat us, your electorate with your heart, not with your wallets. The anger stems from your policies & when we react negatively, its now our fault? Granted, we've never been that gracious or have an entirely open spirit.  Much of that can be attributed to the way we were brought up...home & school...coz its indoctrinated in us from an early age.  We've always been told to listen, toe the line & conform, leaving us little room to express ourselves until social media arrived at the scene.  

I think the govt is very well aware of the real feelings on the ground & much of the content/messages delivered these days are to smooth these feelings over.  Its a start, but the reality is that the govt needs to win over hearts & minds again & start to re-earn the trust that the electorate entrusted on them many years ago.  But pls pls pls, don't chide us citizens in broad brushstrokes.  U have to understand that there'll always be a few outliers.  U must also understand that your policies are the root causes of this anger & mistrust.  We understand that refining these policies take time, but pls don't take too much time.

In conclusion, if the govt is the parent, the electorate (the children) has grown up & its time to treat them as adults & not children.  Thanks. 

In all honesty, I'm very sad that it has come to this state...

This means that upon becoming managers or corporate executives in Singapore, they will not hire locals, choosing instead to exclusively  hire fellow North Indians from the motherland. Much like our new PRC arrivals, their pride over their recent economic success has led them to develop a very aggressive sense  of nationalism and this is displayed when they make condescending  comments about ''stupid Singaporeans''. @Shree Raaman and Tony Seow; I agree with your observations which I have encountered personally in Singapore. A new Indian IT consultant said that he refused to report to his Indian IT Manager who is of a lower caste. He also went on to report that his Indian IT Manager only engaged outsourced under-qualified SAP consultants for the MNC he worked for from his own "secret" external IT company. It was done without the knowledge of the MNC, resulting in conflict of interest. Moreover, the same IT Manager only employed all native comrades from India. As there is no quota for PRs/EP holders, such disturbing trends could be observed in certain companies if the hiring managers are not a Singaporeans and it is challenging to enforce against such outright discrimination. Another local MNC bypass the SPass quota to hire more Foreign IT staff directly at a lower cost by engaging outsourced companies. Maybe, MOM could data mine such disturbing trends or probable discrimination in certain companies if it does not lump PR and Singaporeans together. Are these IT jobs shun by Singaporean IT PME? I doubt so. Hope that govt authorities consider quota for PR/EP holders in companies. We might need FW in jobs that Singaporeans shun, but we definitely do not need too many PRs/FT that would marginalize Singaporean PMEs in the employment process. Dear Sir, certain individual policies from different ministries might have indirectly discourage or deter more Singaporeans to have more children. Hope that the  different govt division policy makers could collaborate closely to derive more down-to-earth & holistic policies that are applicable to all common Singaporeans. It would definitely help if the elite policy makers/consultants (Various levels) could regularly "walk the talk" personally to ensure that any policies are relevant, fair, realistic & beneficial to the common Singaporeans generally.
For a higher Singaporeans birth rate, the areas for the govt to focus and to improve are:
1) High HDB price for first timers. Couples start family much later to save more money 1st. Not many first timers have rich parent to help financially.
2) High infant/childcare fees and high healthcare fees for children. Thus, number of children per family would be limited.
3) Lack of reliable & baby/toddler friendly public transport. Overcrowded public transport is definitely not suitable for families with babies/Toddlers. Private school buses keep increasing fees and has fixed pickup time.
4) COE too high for middle income families planning to have more children and where the car is a basic necessity to fetch babies/toddlers to & from childcare centre during limited operating hours and then to reach office promptly. Not all affordable childcare cntr are near the parent's offices/home. There should be a limit to the cars per household, regardless of the social class status(Income group). Similar to property tax, govt should consider imposing much higher tax levy for the 2nd car and 3rd car ownership per household. Moreover,  the govt should avoid having high COE creating an undesirable prominent social class division in Singapore subsequently. Vehicle population could be control by alternative means and should not compromise the crucial objectives for higher Singaporeans birth rate.
5) High tertiary fees and other increasing education costs is quite challenging for lower/middle Singaporean family. More Subsidies, Bursaries and scholarships to be provided to Singaporeans instead of foreign students(PRs). Suggestion for some tertiary Singaporean students to take "stressful" study loan from bank/organization might not be the best Viable option. Please review and ensure really more affordable tertiary education for all Singaporeans. Longer study loan servicing period implies much longer time to start saving money to start a family and have children.
6) Review & further tighten employment controls/numbers on PRs/EP holders in every companies to minimize discrimination against Capable Singaporean PMEs. Singaporeans must be gainfully employed and not underemployed to support a family with children  properly in the long run. Pls review job discrimination against capable Singaporean PMEs who are 40 years old & above too.  In short, Pls consider Job security for Singaporeans 1st which would be key considerations prior to long term family planning.
7) Determine whether High Inflation is partly due to excessive PRs/"FT" in overcrowded space constraint Singapore. Consider more affordable healthcare with more subsidies for Singaporeans children. Further healthcare subsidies reduction for non-Singaporeans.
8) Improve safety on the road, especially for vulnerable toddlers & children. Strict enforcement of Road Traffic Act on errant cyclists speeding recklessly on pedestrian footpath/crossing endangering road users especially those families walking with their babies/toddlers. Non-compliant foreigners driving/cycling habits should not be condoned to become a dangerous "Norm" in Singapore. Thank you.
