I came from SriLanka with my wife and 4 children to work as an engineer in 1992. My wife suffered during the Civil ethnic war in SriLanka while I was in UK studying. Initialy it was very hard to adopt, to get school , pay for the house rent and have to manage with the very small balance. But the Singaporeans never made noise like now , they helped and though we did not have any relatives we were not felt, specially my wife and children.

I came here to escape the war even leaving my UK PR status because Singapore is like another town near my hometown. I came with MSc. in civil engineering qualification which will cost S$ 500K if Singapore want to invest in some one in Singapore if you can find one. I have brought 3 boys and a girl , increase the size of Singaporean pool.
So it is a win win situation for me as well Singapore.

Hi Christine: No. NGOs, VWOs, Stat Boards have to work together to provide holistic care to the needy. There is no one size fit all in any policies, hence partnering with NGOs and VWOs can help close gaps and provide assistance. I believe this is targeted and effective. 

The fundamental values to provide assistance to any needy families is to help them rebuild their lives and be self dependent. I think various policies and schemes are created to help families with employment (full-time) and also take care of their other immediate concerns like housing, schooling and elder care. 

In which way did the government inflict wounds on the people? 
If you have notice cases that need assistance (e.g. picking up cardboards and others), go to them and ask if they need help. 

I have seen and called the Comcare hotline and someone is readily available to provide assistance whether if they are homeless or in crisis. Heard on the radio that there is even COMCARE.SG that you visit to find the necessary assistance for those elderly. 

You can make the difference. There are various approach and schemes to help. If you don't trust the government, there is also temple assistance (food distribution and shelter too). It is whether we want to do it.

Dear sir, With reference to the New Enhanced Subsidies for Part-time diploma programmes, why is our govt giving a 60% subsidy to PRs (foreigners)? Could the relevant agency please provide a reasonable explanation/elaboration? Are there middle income group of Singaporeans who need to take stressful study loans even with the govt subsidies? Is it justifiable for certain Singaporeans to take "stressful" study loan while the govt subsidize foreigners(PRs) heavily and many PRs are having an earlier head start as most PRs don't have NS obligation? If certain Singaporeans need to service their study loans, could they start a family soon? Could the relevant govt policy makers and the MOE consider reviewing (further reduction) the study subsidies for PRs? To strengthen our Singaporean core, there should be more focus on education support/opportunity and Fair employment opportunity for all Singaporeans 1st please. Thank you.

I think that while PRs should rightfully rank lower than Singaporeans in their entitlement to government subsidy, PRs do contribute their part in baking our economic pie which is shared by all. Some PRs also have family members here who are Singaporeans, so benefits from the government to them have spill-over enjoyment by citizens in the PRs' households. To totally exclude them from any government help at all would seem uncharitable of Singaporeans, if not inequitable. Trying to be positive, I maintain hope that any PR enjoying Singaporeans' generosity will feel thankfulness and one day become full-fledged citizens in addition to their sons doing National Service. Realistically, no one can ever be 100% sure of the outcome despite the best of hope ‚Äì we just have to live with the reality in a real world where movements by immigration and emigration have become very fluid; and Singaporeans who decide to venture into other countries for studies, work or living do also look to their foreign hosts for mutual give and take with graciousness in this world.
Thank you

Scope Guy asks, What is a Singaporean core ? This is a good question, and I hope, an idea of what it is, or what it should be, will be distilled out of the constructive conversation that is taking place.  However, with due respect to Score Guy, I am a bit uncomfortable with the name-calling making all out as morons and simpletons. I humbly suggest that this name-calling should be avoided because it tends to distract from intelligent discussion. On the point of intelligent discussion, Scope Guy has put forward an interesting idea: We cannot do this without culture.

I agree very much on the need for a culture. However, developing a culture carries a lot of personal involvement (personal diligence and commitment for one to develop it in himself) in addition to government encouragement through appropriate policies. Excellence in arts, letters, manners, scholarly pursuits, etc. cannot succeed just by government alone. Citizens must learn to collaborate (cooperate) with the government and the latter must learn to accept some messiness with a tolerance of mistakes. If we want greater government tolerance of citizens, the latter must surely reciprocate with their tolerance of the resulting degree of messiness and mistakes whether by
fellow citizens or by government. There must be many Facebook members out there who have ideas better than mine. I look forward to hearing from them.
Best wishes from Taman Jurong residents

@ William, it is the mindset that matters when deciding whether to have children - in terms of whether one sees children as bringing joy, an important part of a family - a happy family, or simply as burden - emotional or financial. The various incentives are important as these do facilitate the decision, but unlikely to be the tilting or determining factors. Likewise, about getting married - though other factors are at play e.g. getting hitched. I have been sharing with many leaders I met that they ought to do more to shape people's mindset with regards to getting married and having children, and it has to start early. This is an emotive issue that cannot be simply addressed through financial incentives.

I hope to be connected with you on Facebook. .

Thank you and look forward to hear from you.

Warmest regards

Prof Sattar Bawany, CEO Centre for Executive Education - CEE Global
